appearances.description: Older friend of the LaRosas who shot this tape. Opens the video sitting in a director’s chair labeled “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS R. ELLIS,” dedicating the tape to James D. and Jimmy Joe. Roams the room interviewing guests, narrating food, and later narrating the pool game. Often signs off as the ‘film director and producer.’

quotes.text: Well, it's your film director and producer, and this tape was made special for you, James D. and Jimmy Joe La Rosa. This is the party that we all enjoyed so much that you gave for your friends and all of us. Thank you. I'm Louie and Nancy. God bless you both and your family.
quotes.context: Opening dedication while seated in a director’s chair, explaining the purpose of the tape.

quotes.text: Frank, I have videoed 90% of what you've said… Don't give it to the FBI.
quotes.context: Reacting to Frank’s long, colorful monologue about crime, cops, and the FBI.

quotes.text: Well, Jim, with that smile of yours, from your friends south, north, east, west, your family, your relatives, Louie and Nancy, we all want to thank you for everything. God bless you and we love you. Keep the good work up. And this is your film director and producer, Louie Ellis.
quotes.context: Closing the tape with a direct message of thanks and love to James D. LaRosa after the pool games.

appearances.description: Family friend and self‑appointed documentarian; his voice is heard joking about filming blasts, signing off, and addressing Jimmy; sometimes identified in‑frame by others.

quotes.text: They say that this golf course will be one of the top ten in the world. I don't think I'm exaggerating. That's what Pete Dye said.
quotes.context: Voiceover while filming Jimmy and crew planning work; Louie relays Pete Dye’s high expectations for the finished course.

quotes.text: And from Louie Ellison, John Nangotti, adios. We'll see you later. Goodbye. We're going to fade out because we've got another job. This is August 2, 1985.
quotes.context: Louie’s sign‑off after filming the successful blasting of old abutments in Simpson Creek.

appearances.description: Chamber friend and long‑time documentarian of local events. Not often on camera, but his presence is implied by the Ellis Productions credit card at the end. Known for filming Chamber and Pete Dye Golf Club–related events.

Voice behind the camera providing running commentary, technical disclaimers, and identifications of guests. References his wife Nancy Ellis and their company Ellis Productions, and describes getting DiMaggio’s autograph for Nancy.

quotes.text: And now, for the special event at the P. Dye Golf Club. Special guest, Joe DiMaggio. Mr. Joe DiMaggio. Special guest at the P. Dye Golf Club.
quotes.context: Opening narration over the Ellis Productions title card and early tent shots, introducing the subject of the reel.

quotes.text: We were not scheduled to video this event, and our seating location made it impossible for us to have a steady hand.
quotes.context: Spoken over early tent footage to explain the shaky, obstructed nature of the images.

quotes.text: They won’t let me film. They won’t let you film? No, but I got news for you. I stopped your camera, and they’re not going to work on it.
quotes.context: Louie jokes about staff trying to stop him from filming while he continues to record from his seat.

quotes.text: That’s Arch. That’s Arch. That is. It’s the governor. It’s the governor.
quotes.context: Whispered as he tries to pick out the governor in the crowd under the tent.

quotes.text: He’s the architect. He’s the one who made the beauty of this golf course. That’s on camera.
quotes.context: Narration over a shot of a man walking toward the tent, making sure the course architect is documented.

quotes.text: At this time, we were not able to pick up the audio portion. There were no sound system in operation at this time. Sorry about that.
quotes.context: Louie repeatedly inserts this explanation over shots of the head table and the priest speaking, acknowledging missing live audio.

quotes.text: PRIMO VIRATE VIUDE USTATE SANGIA CAVETE MAGNA VEGETARIA… QUICK TRANSLATION ADMIRE EVERYTHING TASTE EVERYTHING AND REJOICE IN EVERYTHING FOR THE BLESSING OF GOD AMEN.
quotes.context: He recites and translates a Latin blessing over silent footage of the clergyman at the head table.

quotes.text: I just got Joe DiMaggio to autograph a picture for my wife, Nancy Ellis. The poster had the pictures of Joe DiMaggio, Ted Williams, and Stan Musial. What great heroes on one picture.
quotes.context: Narrated over close‑ups of DiMaggio at the table, describing his personal autograph moment and the significance of the poster.

quotes.text: There’s a proud boy, Justin Velcastro, right next to Joe DiMaggio.
quotes.context: Louie identifies a boy in a photo or shot with DiMaggio, emphasizing the pride of being beside the legend.

quotes.text: I might insert that there may be our next governor. Joe Mangin. Not the little guy, the bigger guy. Joe Mangin.
quotes.context: Spoken over shots of the head table and later repeated over portraits, highlighting a local dignitary he believes could become governor.

quotes.text: TASTE EVERYTHING AND REJOICE IN EVERYTHING FOR THE BLESSING OF GOD AMEN.
quotes.context: A condensed version of the translated blessing, repeated over scenes of guests eating and talking.

appearances.description: Shoots most of the footage, constantly talking to camera, prompting people for names, joking about not being paid and wanting breakfast, and signing his work as “Ellis Productions, Route 50, east on Bridgeport Hill.”

quotes.text: When Jim does it, they do it right.
quotes.context: Commenting on the quality and completeness of the eight bedrooms in the new guest house.

quotes.text: Beautiful, Mr. LaRosa, Jimmy Joe and the crew, whoever. Pete Dye, what a beauty you have created here in the hills of West Virginia.
quotes.context: Filming the back nine and coal‑heritage features from the guest house deck, praising the LaRosas and Pete Dye.

quotes.text: A dream that the LaRosa had and Pete Dye came to the rescue. How do you like that, Pete?
quotes.context: Narrating over shots of the back nine and lakes, framing the course as the realization of the LaRosa dream with Pete Dye’s help.

quotes.text: Folks, that’s the sunrise over the Pete Dye Golf Club… Great day. You just look at that sight up there. Look at that sun gonna come in pretty soon. Isn’t that beautiful over there?
quotes.context: Filming the early‑morning sunrise over the course on October 1, 1994, expressing awe at the scene.

quotes.text: There we are folks, on the back nine, the first official day opening of the Pete Dye Golf Club. Isn’t that beautiful?
quotes.context: Filming the back nine late in the tape, explicitly marking the historic first official day of full 18‑hole play.

appearances.description: Usually behind the camera, but briefly seen in earlier segments in a red blazer and in some field shots. His voice is heard introducing segments and joking with James D. and crew. He is the one being called “Cecil B. DeMille” by Pete Dye.

quotes.text: “The mistake I made in 1978, I told Jim, ‘No charge,’ and brother, he’s held me to it. But I’m so glad that I did it, and somewhere down the line he’ll remember me.”
quotes.context: At the secretary/employee lunch, joking about his decades of filming the project for free and his relationship with James D.

appearances.description: Behind the camera for much of the member‑outing footage; later appears jokingly as “Cecil B. DeMille” in a two‑man bit. His Ellis Productions business card appears on screen. Known for playful narration and meta‑comments about filming “without charge.”

quotes.text: It’s time to say thanks to James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa for this day, the opening of the Pete Dye Golf Club, Clarksburg‑Bridgeport, West Virginia. Day will always be remembered by all. And from Louie and Nancy Ellis and your families, your friends, thanks. Good night, and God bless you.
quotes.context: Closing voice‑over at the end of the day’s footage, offering thanks and a blessing to the LaRosa family and club community.

appearances.description: Primary home‑movie documentarian. Frequently addresses “Louis” in third person, but also identifies himself (“This is Louie Ellis on the camera”) and jokes about not charging for his work. He appears briefly in intro shots in a red blazer as “director.”

quotes.text: If you notice, most of this is being done by hand, and you know it takes a long time, but they want to do it right. That’s the way it’s being done here at Pete Dye’s golf course.
quotes.context: Voiceover as he films workers hand‑raking and grooving the green, emphasizing craftsmanship over speed.

quotes.text: Well, I’m glad to do it, but I know why he wants me to say one more time, no charge. No charge.
quotes.context: Responding to James D.’s thanks, reiterating that he’s filming as a friend and historian, not for pay.

appearances.description: Family friend and self‑appointed documentarian. Rarely on camera but frequently addressed as “Louie” or “Loy,” asked to pan, zoom, and capture specific features. Occasionally jokes on mic about how much time he’s spent filming the course.

quotes.text: I just figured percentage‑wise, I’m a little over 1/7th of my life I’ve spent down this damn golf course… but I’ve enjoyed every bit of it.
quotes.context: Reflecting on a decade of filming the project while talking with LaRosa and friends.

appearances.description: Behind the camera for most of the reel; occasionally heard joking, prompting people, and being thanked on camera; appears briefly in reflections and is referenced by name.

Identified explicitly in the narration as the person filming (“Louie… we call Cecil B. DeMille here in Clarksburg”). He is mostly behind the camera. The narrator notes Louie walked the ground with a bad hip to film this for Pete. Louie briefly speaks near the end, addressing Pete directly and joking about the job and being worked hard by Jim.

quotes.text: Pete, it was nice doing this job and I hope we did what you wanted. With Harris Holt here and James D. and Louie Ellis, how in the hell can you go wrong? See you later, Pete. God bless you.
quotes.context: Louie’s on‑camera sign‑off from high above the 8th hole, addressing Pete Dye directly after a long day of filming and walking the construction site.

appearances.role: On‑site cameraman, narrator, and informal interviewer
appearances.description: Appears at the very start in a red blazer as “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS F. ELLIS,” then mostly behind the camera. His voice introduces the tape, dates the footage, and frequently hands the mic to others. He jokes about spending a seventh of his life on the course and signs off as the volunteer documentarian.

quotes.text: And now some showing of the Peat Dye LaRosa Golf Course from 10‑16‑90 through 6‑14‑91. Thank you, and this is Louie Ellis. It is Tuesday, October the 16th, 1990.
quotes.context: Opening narration over the first on‑course footage, establishing the time span and Louie’s role as documentarian.

quotes.text: We’re looking at the number one fairway, which is outstanding for the very short period of time that it’s been here. You can see the difference in the greens, in the color of the green, from the fairway to the rough to the fringes of the fairway.
quotes.context: Describing the condition of the #1 fairway on October 16, 1990, while panning across the newly grown turf.

quotes.text: That fairway is just so soft, it just seems like it’s been here for about five years. It has taken a very short period of time for this to green up.
quotes.context: Continuing his assessment of the #1 fairway’s rapid establishment and playability.

quotes.text: What he does, he just contours the ground. That’s after it gets it ready for planting. When he’s finished, then the planting crew will come in to plant the grass. Now Pete Dye has a lot of confidence in this man. He just says go ahead. If Sparky says it’s alright, it’s alright with Pete.
quotes.context: Describing Keith “Sparky” Sparkman’s role shaping #4 green and Pete Dye’s trust in his contouring work.

quotes.text: I just figured percentage‑wise, I’m a little over 70, one‑seventh of my life I’ve spent down this damn golf course… but I’ve enjoyed every bit of it.
quotes.context: Joking on camera with Jim Fazio and Jimmy LaRosa about how much time he’s devoted to filming the project.

appearances.description: Identifies himself in the opening title and in several asides (“This is Louie Ellis…”). Operates the camera across construction and town segments, occasionally appears on camera with a microphone, and conducts interviews and location IDs.

quotes.text: That is the superintendent doing his share and more.
quotes.context: Louie turns the camera on Gary, who has been narrating, to show him working alongside the crew on the green, praising his hands‑on involvement.

appearances.description: Behind the camera for most of the reel; occasionally appears swinging a sledgehammer on the track, joking about being unpaid, or in group shots. Distinctive humorous asides (“no charge,” “I was here since 3 o’clock, Nancy”).

quotes.text: Since 1978… you haven't gave me a dime. And Max, I'll tell you why he hasn't gave me a dime, because I don't want it.
quotes.context: Louie joking on camera about never charging the LaRosas for decades of filming, emphasizing his friendship and voluntary role.

appearances.role: Filmmaker, on‑camera host, and informal interviewer
appearances.description: Appears repeatedly as the man behind and sometimes in front of the camera. Often in casual shirts or a red cardigan, holding a handheld microphone, joking about doing the filming 'no charge.' He prompts others to speak, introduces segments, and later presents a finished tape to Pete Dye.

quotes.text: Well, I’m glad to do it, but I know why. He wants me to say one more time, no charge, and it’s really an honor to be between two fellas.
quotes.context: Louie responds on camera, joking about his unpaid work and expressing his own honor at being part of the LaRosa/Pete Dye project.

quotes.text: Well, we are at the end of our program and from Louie Ellis, your film director and producer, I hope you’ve enjoyed this tape as much as we have doing it for you. Good night and God bless y’all.
quotes.context: Louie signs off at the end of the highlight reel, formally closing the archival program and acknowledging the collaborative effort behind it.

appearances.description: Older man in a red blazer, introduced on camera as “your film director and producer.” He narrates the event, jokes with guests and staff, praises the food, and repeatedly timestamps and contextualizes the party.

quotes.text: This is Louis Ellis, your film director and producer. Tonight is the annual Christmas party by the La Rosa Corporation held at the Nona Maria's restaurant.
quotes.context: On‑camera introduction, establishing himself and the event at the very start of the tape.

quotes.text: And the food is being prepared by that one and only Raymond Priscillo. So I want to say the food was good.
quotes.context: Introductory narration praising the chef and setting up the focus on the buffet.

quotes.text: And God bless you all. And we're going to rate that food 1 to 10 and I rate it number 10. How about that?
quotes.context: Louie’s warm sign‑off and humorous endorsement of the meal during his opening remarks.

quotes.text: It's 12, 15, 89. It's almost 2 o'clock. And we're waiting for the crowd.
quotes.context: Louie timestamps the footage and notes that guests have not fully arrived yet.

quotes.text: The only reason you gave it to me is you didn't want me to stain anything.
quotes.context: Louie jokes back after being given a sample from the buffet.

quotes.text: We have the master carving out the turkey. That's a smoked turkey. Oh, it is? Well, how about that? Raymond has the best.
quotes.context: Narrating at the carving station while praising Raymond’s smoked turkey.

quotes.text: As I always tell your dad, I'm the only non‑paid member of this organization.
quotes.context: Louie jokes about his unofficial role with the LaRosa company.

appearances.description: Shorter man in white short-sleeve shirt and patterned tie in the still snapshot and some on-site shots; identified in text as “Louis P. Ellis – Producer/Director.” He narrates the opening (“here I am, Louis Ellis, with Pete Dye”), expresses admiration for Pete, and closes with his signature “no charge” sign-off.

quotes.text: We have an interview with Pete Dye, James D., Jimmy Joe LaRosa, and part of the working crew. And here I am, Louis Ellis, with Pete Dye. With a snapshot. It's an honor to always be with Pete.
quotes.context: Voiceover introduction over the Ellis Productions title card and a still snapshot of Louie with Pete, framing the footage as an interview and personal keepsake.

quotes.text: We play once a week, every week. I don't care what, I play once a week.
quotes.context: Narration over the still photo of Louie with Pete, emphasizing their regular golf routine and close relationship.

quotes.text: We got Jimmy, James D., CISO, Pete, Bill, Gary, Sparky, Mike. I'll tell you one thing I want to say. Like I said 14 years ago, no charge. And there's no charge today.
quotes.context: Louie begins his closing remarks, listing those present and repeating his long-standing promise to film the project at no charge.

quotes.text: I waited over there and sat there for an hour and a half so I wouldn't miss this fella. And because these guys are tough to find and he's harder. And I've enjoyed every bit of it and I'm glad to have been a part of this organization.
quotes.context: Louie explains his dedication to capturing Pete and the team on film and expresses gratitude for being included.

quotes.text: Somewhere down the line you got all the tapes. You're going to see me and the rest of it. And thank you all for having me do this work. You're great. One more thing… Thank you, Jim. No charge. There will be no retakes. Red light's still on.
quotes.context: Louie underscores that his work has been a labor of love, reiterates “no charge,” and jokes about the camera still rolling.

quotes.text: Well, we are at the end of our interview. Always nice having Pete around. Good night and God bless you all.
quotes.context: Louie formally closes the on-site interview segment with a warm farewell and blessing.

appearances.description: Middle‑aged man, balding with glasses, often in a light short‑sleeve shirt or dark shirt with sunglasses, holding a wired microphone. Introduces the film (“without pay”), interviews James D. and others, and is repeatedly thanked for documenting the project.

Identifies himself on camera in a red blazer as “Film Director & Producer Louis P. Ellis,” and throughout the tape narrates construction scenes, prompts Pete (“Mr. Pete, you’re on now…”), interviews Harris, Gary, Sam Oliverio, and closes the reel with a direct address to Catherine LaRosa.

quotes.text: This tape was made special for you, Catherine LaRose. I hope you’ve enjoyed it as much as I have doing it for you. Thank you, and good night.
quotes.context: Louis closes the program directly to Catherine, framing the entire reel as a personal gift and summing up his role as the family’s unofficial documentarian.

appearances.description: Older man in red blazer and glasses seen in the opening shot with a shoulder‑mounted camera and a director’s chair labeled “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS P. ELLIS.” He is the videographer throughout, providing playful narration and greetings.

quotes.text: August 21, 1993, dinner prepared by Pam Iquina and employees. And this is your film director and producer, Louis Pielas. Goodnight!
quotes.context: Spoken over the opening shot of Louis posing with his camera and director’s chair, and repeated over early buffet and room shots as an audio slate for the event.

quotes.text: Hi Nancy. Pretty girl.
quotes.context: Said as the camera moves through the bar/dining area and focuses on a woman at the bar, indicating familiarity and affection toward a guest named Nancy.

quotes.text: Hi honey. Nice dinner tonight. They put on a good spread, didn’t they? Alright, I’m full. Are you full now? Okay, well, stick around a while and hear the band. All the way down there. We’ll be ready to play golf, right? Okay, bye.
quotes.context: Casual commentary to a companion while filming the bar and stage area, praising the meal, encouraging them to stay for the band, and jokingly referencing golf.

quotes.text: There’s my lawyer, December G. Mousefield. There’s my lawyer.
quotes.context: Spoken jokingly as the camera pans across a table and then a crowded area; Louis humorously identifies an attendee as his “lawyer,” adding personal color to the social footage.

appearances.description: Referred to as “Mr. LaRosa” and “James D.” in the audio. He is spoken about (e.g., bread gift given to him, his rule about Louie paying once doors open) and appears briefly in buffet/bar context, but has limited direct, clear on‑mic speech in this excerpt.

quotes.text: Yes, I'm glad that all my friends are here today. We do business with people that work with us in the company. It seems like we have a nice layout of food. Beautiful. Everybody's in good spirits. Looks like it's going to be a fine party.
quotes.context: Mr. LaRosa gives his host’s message about the party, the guests, and the food.

appearances.description: Older Italian‑American man, central host of the luncheon and home gathering. He repeatedly says he has all his good friends from Florida visiting and that he looks forward to it every year. Seen at the luncheon table and later at home and in the pool room.

quotes.text: I got all my good friends from Florida here to visit with me. I look forward to it every year.
quotes.context: Responding on camera when Louie asks why he’s so happy at the luncheon and later at the home gathering.

quotes.text: I'm just thrilled. I look forward to it now, so you got to come back every year. And next year I might have to charge you because we'll be open for business… I challenged Willie to a pool game… If he doesn't beat Willie, then you're in a lot of trouble… He thought he was going to be the next Willie Mosconi, but he didn't make it, so he took up coal mining. Not bad.
quotes.context: Addressing his Florida friends at the luncheon, inviting them to the pool exhibition at his son’s house and teasing Steve.

quotes.text: I'm going to show us a little bit of your skill here on the lake. We've got a little time… There's no smoking in the house at all… Other than that, it's about ten minutes from here.
quotes.context: Inviting guests to his son’s house for Willie’s pool exhibition and setting house rules.

appearances.role: Founder, on‑site explainer in some segments
appearances.description: Referred to as James D. / Jim LaRosa; appears explaining Simpson Creek work, blasting, and future navigable river and clubhouse plans.

quotes.text: Someday we'll ask you to come back and take this same picture from the same vantage point and no doubt you'll see a very attractive river basin and something that people can use and enjoy.
quotes.context: Addressing Louie while standing near Jimmy Joe’s house, envisioning future "after" shots of a restored, navigable Simpson Creek.

quotes.text: Most everything that we've taken out of the ground on this site, we have used in the construction of this golf course. We've used everything that is native to this part of the country.
quotes.context: Explaining the philosophy of reusing blasted rock and dredged material for walls, banks, and sod base rather than importing materials.

quotes.text: This will also beautify this creek at the same time, because once all this dirt and fill and silt that is down into this creek will be removed, I think this water will turn a real nice pretty green.
quotes.context: Describing how removing rock and silt and reusing it on number 6 will improve both the creek’s appearance and the golf hole.

appearances.role: Founder of Pete Dye Golf Club (mentioned)
appearances.description: Referred to as part of “the LaRosa family” in a feature about the mine portal and coal heritage. Announcers note the family initially wanted to cover mining remnants, but Pete Dye insisted on keeping them as part of the course’s character.
Referenced in booth commentary as “Mr. LaRosa, Jim, the older of the two LaRosas,” who assembled the land in 1979 and gave Pete Dye unusual creative freedom; not seen on camera in these excerpts.

appearances.role: Honoree – Harrison County Chamber of Commerce Citizen of the Year; local developer and golf‑club founder
appearances.description: Older West Virginian businessman, long‑time Clarksburg/Bridgeport resident, recognized for extensive civic, charitable, and business contributions including coal, retail, education, health care, and the Pete Dye Championship Golf Course in Bridgeport. Seen at the podium giving a brief, modest acceptance speech.

quotes.text: I lived here all my life and moved a few times, but never more than a couple miles from my high school. I guess that makes me a native son. That’s what I want to be.
quotes.context: Acceptance speech after receiving the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce Citizen of the Year award.

quotes.text: I want to thank the Chamber and its members for giving me this recognition. I hope in some small way I helped the quality of life for all of us. I couldn’t really accept this without recalling my parents. Without their love, support, teaching, I wouldn’t be standing here.
quotes.context: Continuing his Citizen of the Year acceptance, LaRosa expresses gratitude and credits his parents.

appearances.description: Older LaRosa seen in the construction‑trailer meeting (blue cardigan, white hair) introducing Pete, Max Robertson, and Bob Andrew, and later in on‑course segments in a striped golf shirt. Also appears extensively in the dogs‑and‑cats section, narrating each animal and praising caretaker Bernadine.

quotes.text: We’re trying to finish this front nine here before the weather gets too bad.
quotes.context: In the trailer meeting, James D. explains the immediate construction goal and seasonal pressure, anchoring the footage in the fall 1989 schedule.

quotes.text: There’s a rumor going around about my age, and I don’t believe it… It’s a foul rumor spread by the opposition on a smear campaign.
quotes.context: At his birthday party, James D. jokingly denies being as old as people say, using political language to mock the idea of aging as a scandal.

appearances.role: Founder / owner, on-site with Pete and later introduced as “James D.”
appearances.description: Older Italian-American man in a bright pink dress shirt and dark tie in some shots; elsewhere appears in casual white T-shirt on site. Speaks about the long journey of the project, his son Jimmy Joe running operations, and wanting to make Pete proud.

quotes.text: No, I'm your assistant, Jim. I'll always be your assistant, I guarantee it.
quotes.context: James D. responds to Pete’s joke, humbly positioning himself as Pete’s assistant despite being the owner/founder.

quotes.text: You know, this whole project, I've talked about it for so many years. People wonder, but it's probably been as much fun as I've ever had in my life, trying to put this thing together. Sometimes I get just a little frustrated, but not too often.
quotes.context: James D. reflects on the long journey of building the club, acknowledging both the challenges and the joy.

quotes.text: I'd like to say something about my son Jimmy Joe here. He's going to run the operation. This is his son Jameson here. I don't know much about the game of golf or how he's running the golf business, so I'm totally confident in Jimmy Joe running this operation.
quotes.context: James D. publicly hands operational responsibility to his son Jimmy Joe and expresses full confidence in him.

quotes.text: I'd like to make Pete proud of it. He's built it for us, and now we've got to maintain a certain level of quality that befits his genius. I guess it goes together, the design and the condition.
quotes.context: James D. articulates his desire to honor Pete’s work by maintaining high standards of conditioning and operations.

appearances.description: Appears near the end identifying himself as “James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad,” calling himself “the chaplain” and expressing pride in the big day. Central symbolic figure of the opening.

quotes.text: Oh, I’m the chaplain. And every time I go around, there’s like three signs: Praise the Lord. And I’m James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad. I’m having a big, special day here today. I really got it going. I’m proud of the whole organization.
quotes.context: Closing on‑camera statement near the end of the tape, expressing pride and humor about his role and the day’s significance.

quotes.text: Hi, Mrs. Nance. I want to say hi to Nancy Ellis. Thank you, Nancy. Make it more available to us, your support.
quotes.context: Addressing Louie’s wife Nancy directly, thanking her for her support of the project and the family.

appearances.description: Appears both in the field and in the wood‑paneled meeting room. In the field he stands on graded fairways and in lake basins, holding a microphone, explaining yardages, green revisions, lake depths, and construction logistics. In the office he sits in a blue cardigan, discussing design, finances, and staff like Joe Hall and Keith Sparkman.

quotes.text: “This is going to be one of the biggest golf holes in the world in terms of length, width, and visibility.”
quotes.context: Standing on the 11th fairway/green area, describing the revised 630‑yard par‑5 and its 120‑yard‑wide landing area.

quotes.text: “This type of work has been going on for 16 years… We think sometime around the middle of July we’ll be all seeded down and finally, after all these years, ready to tee it up.”
quotes.context: Narrating from the 15th lake and practice range area about the long duration of earthmoving and the impending completion of seeding.

quotes.text: “We’re down to our last two or three weeks of construction. We think sometime around the middle of July we’ll be all seeded down and finally, after all these years, we’re just about ready to tee it up here in about two months.”
quotes.context: Summarizing the endgame of earthmoving and seeding while showing topsoil being hauled to the practice range and 15th fairway.

quotes.text: “We may end up calling it Lake Reel in honor of their family name.”
quotes.context: Standing with Larry Reel and others beside the 15th lakes, joking about naming the lake after the Reel brothers who built it.

appearances.description: Older Italian‑American man (likely the one with tinted glasses and dark blazer at the head table) who calls the course his “labor of love,” thanks Pete for spending all the money he had and could borrow, and recounts designing holes himself (like #18) and being overruled, plus the oak‑tree and gob‑pile anecdotes. He frames the 17‑year build as his life’s work.

quotes.text: This golf course is my thing in life, it’s my labor of love, and I don’t think that I could have shared it with anybody else in this manner than I have with you.
quotes.context: James D. addresses Pete directly, describing the 17‑year project as the defining work of his life and praising their partnership.

quotes.text: Gob is a coal slate and impurities that they separate from the coal and throw in a pile outside of a coal mine in the old days… this slate then catches fire and just smolders for years and years and years.
quotes.context: Jim explains the mining waste that once covered the property, setting up the transformation of a smoldering gob pile into the 10th hole.

appearances.description: Older Italian‑American man who repeatedly narrates construction progress, explains Pete Dye’s intentions, introduces workers, and interviews guests. Often holds a handheld microphone and speaks directly to Louie behind the camera.

quotes.text: The only thing is the first 30 feet of what appears to be green is not actually green. The green starts about where that first white stake is.
quotes.context: Clarifying to Monsignor O’Reilly that the approach is built to green specs but isn’t part of the official putting surface.

quotes.text: He tells us what to do, and then we do it, and then he usually comes in and makes some last minute, I call it subtleties, that he puts into the course.
quotes.context: Describing Pete Dye’s process of giving instructions, then returning to refine holes like the seventh with subtle contour changes.

quotes.text: The house was a Georgian mansion built in 1842… we removed all of the house from the premises… except the four outside walls were a pink brick that probably, if it stayed, would give more character around this hole.
quotes.context: Describing the demolished Smith mansion and how its stone was reused for the seventh tee wall.

appearances.description: Older Italian‑American man, often speaking directly to camera on construction sites and inside the temporary clubhouse, explaining irrigation, cart paths, clubhouse plans, and introducing workers.

quotes.text: Today we’re working on the irrigation of the 8th hole. And it’s September the 5th, Italian Festival Day, but we need to work every day this month in order to get this hole upsoiled, irrigated, and seeded. Otherwise we’ll lose the whole growing season. So we missed the Italian Festival Parade this morning, but we’ll see you next year, I guess.
quotes.context: On‑camera explanation at the 8th hole construction site about schedule pressure and working through a local holiday.

quotes.text: We’re looking at the T end of the 8th golf hole here, which we think this golf hole is going to be one of the 8 wonders of the golfing world.
quotes.context: Standing on the raw tee end of the 8th hole, describing its future significance while Louie films the dramatic high wall and fairway corridor.

quotes.text: The ditch is about 36 inches deep. We want to get below the crust. And then we put the wiring in and then we put the pipe. And then we put sand in… that gives a bed for the pipe and wire. So if there’s any rocks that end up in the ditch, sometimes you need a bed.
quotes.context: Narrating over close‑ups of irrigation trenches and workers laying pipe and control wire on the 8th hole.

quotes.text: This here is a border that goes on top of the chair rail… It’s a paper that gives you the so‑called Pinehurst feeling, which is a conservative, quiet Scottish look. It’s what Jimmy Joe wanted in his pro shop.
quotes.context: Inside the temporary clubhouse, showing wallpaper and fabric samples for the grill room and pro shop décor.

quotes.text: We have drawings for the temporary clubhouse here at the Pete Dye Golf Club designed by Robert Pernell, architect… Very, very good architect. He’s done other work for us in the past.
quotes.context: Pointing to architectural blueprints for the temporary clubhouse and locker rooms.

quotes.text: We’re standing in front of number one lake at the Pete Dye Golf Club, two days before the opening. The men you see in the picture are some of the men that have worked with us to build this course… I wanted to preserve this picture so I can think of the good times and the hard times and the problems we’ve had during this course.
quotes.context: Introducing the assembled crew for a group portrait and roll‑call before opening day.

quotes.text: Someday I’ll be looking at this again and thinking of you, Louie, and Nancy, because you couldn’t get this done without her.
quotes.context: Inside the temporary clubhouse, thanking Louie and Nancy Ellis for their long‑term filming and support.

appearances.role: Developer / founder, voiceover subject, inset portrait ID
appearances.description: Identified on-screen by a circular inset portrait labeled “James D. LaRosa.” His words are heard in voiceover discussing his personal connection to the project, business rationale, and belief in West Virginia’s resort potential. He does not appear speaking live on camera in this excerpt, but his portrait is used over scenic B‑roll.

quotes.text: For the planned Burning Embers Resort project, it is significant to me personally to have this project located in my home state and hometown. But as a businessman, the project represents more than personal satisfaction.
quotes.context: Voiceover from LaRosa, accompanied by his inset portrait over scenic course shots, expressing both personal pride and business perspective.

quotes.text: I believe in West Virginia's potential for recreational and resort development. Our geographical location in proximity to major metropolitan areas, our existing modern highway and air travel transportation system, our natural and unspoiled scenic beauty are desirable features for those looking for a special place to relax and gather for business and recreational reasons.
quotes.context: LaRosa articulates the strategic case for the Burning Embers Resort and Pete Dye Golf Club as part of a broader vision for West Virginia tourism and recreation.

appearances.role: Founder / owner, on‑camera host and explainer
appearances.description: Not named explicitly in every shot, but appears as an older, well‑dressed man in some interview segments and as the person being praised by others. He is referenced in third person (“Mr. LaRosa requested you to come with me,” “Jim here I have to say… he’s been very successful… come up the hard way through the Depression”). He participates in on‑site commentary and is the “head honcho” Harris greets.

appearances.role: Founder; subject of birthplace and family‑home segments
appearances.description: Not clearly seen speaking in this reel, but repeatedly referenced (“Jim,” “James D.,” “Papa Jim”). Buildings tied to him are shown: his birthplace, the Martin & LaRosa building, the Home Hotel, and his family home with lion statues.

Appears multiple times explaining design decisions (coal cinder bunkers, 4th and 18th holes, mine-themed features) and speaking directly to Louie. Older Italian-American man in dress shirt and tie or casual short-sleeve shirt, often authoritative but warm.

quotes.text: These coal cinders… are out of a wet bottom furnace, electric utility plant, and they have a metallic finish to them, and they'll kind of glisten when the sun shines. We just hope that the ball doesn't sink too deep in them when they're hit very high and land hard.
quotes.context: Explaining the experimental coal cinder bunkers on the 1st hole and their aesthetic and playability implications.

quotes.text: We're all very proud of it. We know we're going to have the greatest golf course in the world. We're not going to quit until we get to that point.
quotes.context: Group scene near the 4th/10th corridor, expressing the LaRosa team’s ambition for the course.

quotes.text: These fish… are special fish that you need the permission of the State Department of Natural Resources to have them brought into the state. They will not multiply… and they won't eat anything but grass or anything green.
quotes.context: Describing triploid carp being stocked into the No. 1 lake and their ecological role in controlling algae and cattails.

quotes.text: These pictures were taken by the one and only L.P. Ellis. And you were really here today since 3 o'clock, Nancy. I'll vouch for you, Louie.
quotes.context: Thanking Louie for his filming and reassuring Nancy Ellis on camera that Louie was indeed on the course all afternoon.

appearances.role: Course founder / owner / primary on‑site narrator
appearances.description: Older white‑haired man, often in a white V‑neck T‑shirt or light polo, frequently holding a handheld microphone. Seen in construction areas, at scenic overlooks, and in a hospital gown with his arm in a cast, explaining the project’s history, design, and progress.

quotes.text: “We’ve been working on the golf course for about nine years. This will be the 10th year and hopefully the year that we complete the course so it’s ready for play in 1989.”
quotes.context: Office and on‑site interviews where James D. outlines the long development timeline and target opening year.

quotes.text: “We built this course on 235 acres of ground. It’s part of a thousand‑acre tract of ground. It’s going to have three lakes. Simpson Creek winds through the course and comes into play on four holes.”
quotes.context: Introductory explanation of the course’s physical scale and integration with Simpson Creek.

quotes.text: “We’re going to put a dam in the creek so we don’t have the constant width of about 90 feet. And that way it will keep its integrity as a wide creek or river.”
quotes.context: Describing planned water management to maintain a broad, river‑like feature through the course.

quotes.text: “I had an accident. It was my fault. I was walking where I shouldn’t have been walking… Just at the time I got to where they were working, this particular tree that was leaning, they had just cut it in two and it was on its way down with the force of the bulldozer. So I didn’t even know what hit me.”
quotes.context: From his hospital bed, recounting the tree‑clearing accident behind the 8th hole that injured his arm.

quotes.text: “This lake is about three and a half acres in area and it averages about eight foot in depth… It aerates the water to keep the water so it would support fish life and also to cut down on the algae.”
quotes.context: Describing the 4th‑hole lake and its floating fountain, explaining both aesthetic and ecological functions.

quotes.text: “We’ve done this work with the use primarily of scrapers and bulldozers and we’ve hauled it anywhere from 500 to 1,500 feet away from this lake and put it where it was needed.”
quotes.context: Standing in the bottom of the 15th‑hole lake, explaining how lake excavation material was reused to shape bunkers and mounds around the course.

quotes.text: “We know we’re going to have the greatest golf course in the world. We’re not going to quit until we get to that point.”
quotes.context: Standing with P.B. Dye, Drew Pearson, and others on the 4th fairway, expressing the team’s ambition and determination.

quotes.text: “These wonderful pictures are taken by Louie Ellis, the one and only Louie Ellis. He’s been my friend and accommodated me so much over these last few years on this golf course.”
quotes.context: At the coal pit, thanking Louie for documenting the project and emphasizing the value of the footage for posterity.

appearances.role: Founder / owner, on‑site narrator and interview subject
appearances.description: Older, white‑haired man in dress shirts, sometimes with a red tie, sometimes in a white V‑neck T‑shirt or tan coat. He narrates construction at Simpson Creek, explains the clubhouse and lake plans, praises workers, and often thanks Louie. He appears both in construction-era footage (early 1980s) and later scenic/stocking/fountain sequences.

quotes.text: Louie, I want to thank you for taking these pictures of our operation. We’ll always appreciate having them, I know, for our own historical reasons, but you’ve been a friend down through the years, and what you’re doing now is awfully nice.
quotes.context: On-site in 1982 near Simpson Creek, James D. addresses Louie directly, acknowledging that the filming is being done as a favor and as a conscious historical record of the project.

appearances.description: Appears briefly in an inset ID shot as an older man in a suit labeled “James D. LaRosa,” delivering formal, scripted narration about the land, West Virginia’s potential, and the course’s connection to coal heritage and golf tradition. His words are also used extensively as voiceover copy throughout the film.
Not seen in this reel but repeatedly referenced as approving stonework, wanting natural/old‑looking materials, and predicting a top‑ten course.

Discussed in a narrated feature as the designer of Pete Dye Golf Club and many famous courses. Announcers say he was on site earlier in the week for the pro‑am and call the course “18 of his most memorable holes.”

Discussed extensively as the course designer; commentary notes this is the only course bearing his name, built on a reclaimed coal mine, and likely his favorite project due to creative freedom; not seen on camera in these clips.

appearances.role: Golf course architect; main interview subject
appearances.description: Appears repeatedly in the October 6, 1989 construction‑trailer and on‑course interviews, in a light sweater and glasses, joking about his name and the difficulty of the 8th hole, and giving detailed commentary on strategy, contours, and aesthetics.

quotes.text: My name is Pete Dye. D for Ducky, Y for Yoko, and B for Ever the H. How about that? Dye.
quotes.context: Louis prompts Pete in the trailer‑office to state his name on camera; Pete responds with a playful, nonsensical spelling that sets a humorous tone for the interview.

quotes.text: You can’t play the eighth hole. The only place is a seven hole golf course. You get to eight, you stop. You can’t drive a car, you can’t play it. It’s all there.
quotes.context: Continuing the name joke, Pete and James D. riff on the notorious difficulty of the 8th hole, framing it as almost unplayable and emblematic of the course’s toughness.

quotes.text: I told Max, I’ll never live long enough, but there’s nothing like this golf course in the United States. Nothing. I know it’s the best or it’s the worst, but let’s put nothing in the equal.
quotes.context: In the Oct 6, 1989 trailer interview, Pete reflects on the uniqueness and extremity of the design, acknowledging it could be polarizing but insisting it has no equal.

quotes.text: The views, the vistas, the way it looks, the visual appearance, there’s not another golf course I’ve ever seen in the United States.
quotes.context: Pete elaborates on why he considers the course unique, emphasizing the surrounding mountains, mining landscape, and visual drama as central to its identity.

quotes.text: Member players, they don’t mind the bunkers, they don’t mind the water, they don’t mind the hazards, as long as you can just get the area cleaned up where they can find the ball… As long as they can negotiate, they’ll play golf.
quotes.context: Discussing playability, Pete explains that golfers accept hazards if they can find and hit their ball, arguing for cleaning up woods and underbrush rather than softening strategic features.

quotes.text: You should never talk about your children or your golf course. I’ve never had any opportunity like this… This has got something else. It really does.
quotes.context: Comparing this project to others, including his Dominican Republic work, Pete admits he’s never had a site like this and hints at a personal, almost parental attachment to the course.

quotes.text: Not changes, Jim. They’re modifications. You’ve got to modify. They’re additions.
quotes.context: Responding to a question about changes made that day, Pete reframes them as “modifications” and “additions,” revealing his iterative design mindset.

quotes.text: Well, Jimmy, you know, you’re going to be a much better commentator after 11½ years. You and Louie have got this thing down pat… God knows we’ve always felt the potential is really here in Clarksburg more so than any place I’ve ever seen.
quotes.context: On Sept 28, 1990, Pete teases Jimmy about his on‑camera skills, then earnestly praises the Clarksburg site’s potential during the #1 green celebration.

quotes.text: Sparky… we just finished a golf course that had 10 holes on the ocean and not a house in sight… When he came back here to work this fall he says, ‘Pete, there’s nothing like Jim LaRosa’s job here in Clarksburg.’ And I said, ‘Well, Sparky, for God’s sakes, we’ve got to get her finished before we all drop from this world.’
quotes.context: Pete recounts Keith “Sparky” Sparkman’s praise for the project and uses it to underscore both the course’s uniqueness and the urgency to complete it.

appearances.role: Golf course architect and primary on-camera storyteller
appearances.description: Older man in light flat cap, glasses, white/light long-sleeve shirt, often with arms folded or gesturing while standing on the dirt construction site. He tells the Clinton/Quickstick story and gives detailed commentary on course evolution and green speeds.

quotes.text: And they had 17 guys out there going around with us on the golf course. And they didn't let the press go, so it was just the governor and Clinton and myself.
quotes.context: On the construction site, Pete describes the heavy security and exclusivity of a fundraising round with President Clinton and a governor at Crooked Stick.

quotes.text: Clinton was dark when we were coming down the 16th hole of Crooked Stick. I mean, it gets darker and heavier. And these guys are just paranoid trying to get him off the golf course. ‘Wait a minute, wait a minute, can't we do it?’
quotes.context: Pete recounts security’s anxiety as daylight fades and Clinton insists on continuing the round, entertaining the assembled crew.

quotes.text: Woody, you worried about a submarine coming out of that goddamn pond and gonna take a shot at the goddamn president? I said, all those Republicans that live in those houses over there, I said, you guys better get the hell over there by those bushes.
quotes.context: Punchline of Pete’s Clinton story, joking with security chief Woody Mellon about where the real threat might come from, drawing laughter from the group.

quotes.text: You know, you have to work on a golf course. Golf courses are a growing thing. The minute somebody says, ‘Don't change the original design,’ it's an erroneous statement.
quotes.context: Pete transitions from anecdote to design philosophy, arguing that courses must evolve with equipment, players, and nature.

quotes.text: I know if Donald Ross was alive today and he was back at his favorite spot, Pinehurst No. 2, and he saw Brandie Burton hit a drive and a 9-iron to the first green, he'd move the tee back into the parking lot.
quotes.context: Illustrating his point about course evolution by imagining how Donald Ross would react to modern power golf.

quotes.text: Ever since we built it, it's been over 20 years, and the membership, you know, they're very protective of that golf course. When I cleared Harbour Town and made the corridor to the fairway, they were pretty tight. And in 20 years, the pine trees have grown in 15 feet on each side. Now you take 30 feet, that's tremendous, tremendous.
quotes.context: Pete explains how tree growth has dramatically narrowed Harbour Town’s corridors, and how members resist necessary tree removal.

quotes.text: They built the greens in 1964, and they didn't have any modern equipment to cut the greens as fast as they do today. So for the PGA, I went back and softened all the greens so they would be acceptable to the boys.
quotes.context: Discussing Crooked Stick’s greens and how advances in mowing technology forced him to soften contours for championship play.

quotes.text: The greens are almost out of date before they're built. But today, I think we've got them pretty well in tone of what we know what they're playing today. So I think that the greens will putt acceptably to all kinds of speed. And I think that the test of golf is here.
quotes.context: Pete concludes his design commentary by asserting that Pete Dye Golf Club’s greens are tuned to modern speeds and will provide a lasting test.

quotes.text: I felt like I've worked on this 15th hole in different places around the world, but I've never had a setting like this. I may never have a setting like this. I'll never have a setting like this ever.
quotes.context: Standing on the unfinished 15th, Pete praises the unique natural setting and suggests it’s unmatched in his career.

quotes.text: Am I your assistant, or are you my assistant?
quotes.context: Light-hearted exchange as Pete and James D. joke about their working relationship in front of the camera.

appearances.description: Not seen speaking in this tape, but repeatedly praised by Louie as the designer who “came to the rescue” and created “what a beauty” in the hills of West Virginia.

Seen in the indoor meeting segment (balding, glasses, beige sweater). He speaks at length about strategy, topography, the balance of the front and back nines, and the concept for the 17th green. His comments are philosophical and comparative (Crooked Stick, St Andrews, Augusta).

quotes.text: “There’s nothing like this golf course in the United States. Nothing. I don’t know whether it’s the best or it’s the worst, but let’s put it this way: there’s nothing equal to this one today. The views, the vistas, the way it looks, the visual appearance—there’s not another golf course I’ve ever seen in the United States this dramatic.”
quotes.context: In the office trailer with James D., reflecting on the front nine and the site’s topography compared to other courses like Crooked Stick.

quotes.text: “Maybe 17 might be the best hole we’ll get done, the most talked‑about hole I’ve ever done. And Jim came up with the idea… He really did. I said make a small green. He said, ‘I’m going to make one four times bigger than it’s supposed to be.’”
quotes.context: Explaining the concept for the 17th green and crediting James D. LaRosa for inspiring the idea, even though Pete reversed the original suggestion.

quotes.text: “You build a golf course like this, a really demanding piece of ground, and you finally get all the area around it cleaned up underbrush so a person can play the game… They don’t mind the bunkers, they don’t mind the water, they don’t mind the hazards, as long as you just get an area cleaned up where they can find a ball and they’ll beat it out of the ditches, they’ll beat it out of the bunkers. But you can’t let them slice off into the woods… As long as they can negotiate, they’ll play golf.”
quotes.context: In the office, explaining his philosophy that great courses are demanding but playable if players can find and advance the ball.

quotes.text: “He used to steal coal off of Jim LaRosa… now his conscience has bothered him, so that’s why he’s doing this now.”
quotes.context: Teasing Louie Ellis in the office, after calling him ‘Cecil B. DeMille’ and joking that his filming is payback for stolen coal.

appearances.description: Older white‑haired man in a light sport coat and striped shirt at the head table. He jokes about not being called “Modest Pete,” thanks the on‑site team (Gary, Billy, Mark Shaw), tells the tunnel/Miracle Mountain story from his perspective, teases Jim about not being able to play golf, explains his design philosophy (subtleties, depressions, mounds, trees), answers questions about trips, government and housing‑development constraints, and assesses the club’s chances of hosting majors.

quotes.text: Some people know how to design and some people know how to play. And he says, I can do it.
quotes.context: Pete’s reported response when Jim asked if he could work with the other design firm on the Simpson Creek site, asserting his confidence in handling the design alone.

quotes.text: If you do, call it the Miracle Mountain Golf Course. It would be a miracle if anybody wanted to play it.
quotes.context: Pete’s blunt verdict on the original mountain site, explaining why he initially turned down the job and pushing Jim to find better ground.

quotes.text: You dummy, don’t you see that the river’s going down and I want this hole to play down? Don’t go against nature.
quotes.context: Pete’s reaction when he saw Jim had spent $40,000 building #18 uphill; he insists on working with the natural fall of the land and space for galleries.

quotes.text: I never met a man that can’t play golf that loves golf as much as Jim LaRosa. That’s a pretty strong statement.
quotes.context: Pete teasingly praises Jim’s passion for golf despite his poor playing ability, highlighting Jim’s emotional investment in the game and the club.

quotes.text: Before you all put them in the headlines I’ve knocked down, I’ve planted more trees than anybody in this whole world, probably the biggest tree lover ever, but every once in a while you get them on a golf course, it just drives you crazy.
quotes.context: Pete defends his reputation as a tree lover while justifying the removal of certain trees, like the seven oaks on #2, for strategic design reasons.

quotes.text: All your golf courses are your kids, you know. You build one for a dirt golf course or a golf course like this.
quotes.context: Pete answers a question about his most challenging designs, likening all his courses to his children and emphasizing his attachment to each project.

quotes.text: When I walked in here and saw this ground, yes, it was all torn up from the coal, but you could see the routing going down and coming back… this will never happen again, has never happened before, will never happen again to me to have something like to build on a ground like this.
quotes.context: Pete explains why the Simpson Creek site was uniquely suited to a great golf course and why he kept returning over 17 years.

quotes.text: I’ve been here over 17 years. I think if I make it back another time, I’ll make 400 trips. That’s about the total that some of my competitors make in their whole lifetime on all their jobs.
quotes.context: Pete responds to a question about how many trips he made to the site, highlighting his extraordinary personal involvement in this project.

quotes.text: I don’t think being in Clarksburg or outside of the mainstream of the metropolitan area in 10 or 15 years is going to make a lot of difference in major championships… hopefully 20 years from now there will still be some area around Clarksburg to park a car and things like that.
quotes.context: Pete discusses the future of major championships, television logistics, and why Pete Dye Golf Club’s remote location may not be a barrier if infrastructure is preserved.

quotes.text: Jim and I are pretty dumb, but we’re not stupid, are we Jim?
quotes.context: Pete jokingly answers a question about inviting tour pros to critique the course, suggesting they’re not eager to bring in critics.

appearances.description: Appears in later greens-construction segment (tan cap, tan sweater, glasses) speaking about the Clarksburg site, the potential of the land, and his long collaboration with shaper Keith Sparkman. His comments are framed by others as those of the course’s designer.
Appears in archival interview/voiceover describing his philosophy for the closing holes (16–18) and is discussed extensively by commentators and Jimmy LaRosa as the mastermind behind the course.

quotes.text: You know, I try to finish the golf courses strong. And I think 16 is a strong, certainly a strong par 3. You’re going to find 17 quite controversial, but it’s a short par 4 and it’s got a knobby old green, probably too knobby, but they’ll talk about it, certainly. But 18, I think, is a wonderful finishing hole.
quotes.context: Pre‑recorded interview segment where Dye explains his design intent for the closing stretch at Pete Dye Golf Club.

appearances.description: Older man with white hair and glasses, labeled on screen in one segment. Speaks into a microphone about bunker shaping and how he wants misses to roll into sand.

appearances.role: Intended recipient of the footage; course architect
appearances.description: Not seen on camera in this material, but addressed constantly in second person. The entire walkthrough is framed as a visual report for Pete to review contours, drainage, bunkers, and green edges, so he can “tell us what to do over the phone.”

appearances.role: Golf course architect and on‑camera interview subject
appearances.description: Appears repeatedly in circular inset interview footage wearing a light bucket hat, glasses, and a light sweater or vest, holding a microphone while standing outdoors on the course with others. He speaks at length about the property’s drama, design strategy, and what makes great golf courses.

quotes.text: I don't think I've ever seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property. I don't know how else you can say it. There isn't anything more dramatic than this.
quotes.context: Displayed as an on-screen quote over aerial footage and echoed in narration to emphasize the uniqueness of the West Virginia site.

quotes.text: All great golfers, you know, what makes great golf courses usually have the Pacific Ocean on one side or the Atlantic Ocean on the other side or a mountain or something that it's hard to reproduce. Well, the general topography right through here, you know, of this part of the country, you can't reproduce it.
quotes.context: Spoken in on-site interview footage while scenic shots of the course and surrounding hills play, explaining why this inland property can stand alongside famous seaside courses.

quotes.text: So when you play this golf course or a golf course like this, I mean, it's different. You feel like you're a million miles away from any given place and you can't look in any direction and not have a great vista.
quotes.context: Part of Dye’s extended commentary on the course’s atmosphere and vistas, over shots of fairways, rivers, and hills.

quotes.text: Now every hole here has a distinctive look to it and a great background. So then if we can come up with a variation of the holes and make the strategy as good as any golf course in the country and you have a strategy along with what's here naturally, it's the hillside, the mountainside, and work it into it.
quotes.context: Explaining his design philosophy for Pete Dye Golf Club, emphasizing both strategic variety and integration with the natural terrain.

quotes.text: When you have a hilly golf course, there's a lot of real hilly golf courses that are not good strategy golf holes. But out here, I assure you that every golf hole we have out here, we have a terrific variation of strategy — short, long, different.
quotes.context: Defending the strategic quality of the course despite its hilly terrain, over visuals of contoured fairways and valleys.

quotes.text: Most golf courses, you come into an area like this, it's hard to get it done to where it really looks like a finished product. And now we're getting this getting closer and closer where it looks like every hole has been finished.
quotes.context: Discussing the long-term effort and detailing required to make the course feel truly finished, rather than merely playable.

quotes.text: A lot of times when the golf course is open for play or a developer jumps in and you've got six months to build a golf course, you have to get it open the day after tomorrow. It's not really — it's open for play, but it's not finished.
quotes.context: Critiquing rushed golf developments while contrasting them with the decade-long build at Pete Dye Golf Club.

quotes.text: Well, this golf course, in my opinion now, is getting all the small touches that you need to give it an individual character.
quotes.context: Praising the current stage of refinement at Pete Dye Golf Club, particularly the detailing that gives each hole its own identity.

quotes.text: For example, the work they've done on number four. Well, four has been sitting there as a great golf hole for almost four years. And now that we're starting to make it look more like a finished hole, everybody starts to see it.
quotes.context: Using hole 4 as a case study in how visual finishing work reveals the quality of an already-strong design.

quotes.text: You know, a golf course is like Augusta National. It's a great golf course and it has a certain atmosphere. But just going in Magnolia Drive, it's impressive. And so it doesn't have anything to do with strategy, golf course, or anything, but it's just a little short drive. Well, I assure you that the drive coming into this golf course is equally, if not more so, impressive.
quotes.context: Comparing the entrance experience at Pete Dye Golf Club to Augusta National’s Magnolia Drive, emphasizing the importance of arrival atmosphere.

quotes.text: So you start right out at the Smith Chapel and make that turn, and then when you start to get back that road, you feel the minute you make that turn to go back there that you're going to some place, you're going to something.
quotes.context: Describing the emotional impact of the entrance road and how it sets expectations for the course experience.

quotes.text: You created something here in the middle of West Virginia that is unheard of.
quotes.context: Summarizing the uniqueness and ambition of the project in a region not typically associated with world-class golf.

appearances.description: Not clearly visible in this reel but frequently referenced as the designer approving and changing greens, specifying Scottish bunkers, and having many top-100 courses.

Older man with light/white hair, seen on‑site in a sweater and bucket hat, speaking into a microphone about the property’s drama, strategy, and finishing touches. Also appears hitting test shots on a par‑3 under construction.

quotes.text: “I don’t think I’ve ever seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property. I don’t know how else you can say it. There isn’t anything more dramatic than this.”
quotes.context: On‑site with James D. and crew, praising the property’s topography and vistas.

quotes.text: “When you play this golf course… you feel like you’re a million miles away from any given place, and you can’t look in any direction and not have a great vista.”
quotes.context: Explaining how the surrounding landscape contributes to the course’s greatness, beyond strategy and green contours.

quotes.text: “Most golf courses, you come into an area as big as this, it’s hard to get it done to where it really looks like a finished product. Well, this golf course, in my opinion now, is getting all the small touches that you need to give it an individual character.”
quotes.context: Discussing the importance of finishing details—rock work, mounding, entrance road—in giving the course a unique, finished feel.

appearances.description: Not seen speaking, but repeatedly referenced by commentators as the designer of Pete Dye Golf Club and its “18 most memorable holes.”

quotes.text: He’s the toughest, most tenacious, never-give-up son of a gun I ever worked for.
quotes.context: Referenced by the commentators as a known quote about James D. LaRosa; not spoken directly in this footage but part of the broader Pete Dye Golf Club story.

appearances.description: Older man with white hair, often in casual golf clothes and cap. He appears in on‑course discussions (e.g., at the coal‑mine hole and later when asked to rate the course), talking about strategy, self‑contained design, coal heritage, and comparisons to Scottish courses and St Andrews.

quotes.text: I don’t think I’ve ever seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property. I don’t know how else you could say it. There isn’t anything more dramatic than this.
quotes.context: Standing with James D. and Jimmy on the front nine, Pete describes the uniqueness of the West Virginia site, emphasizing its topography and vistas.

quotes.text: All great golf courses… usually you have the Pacific Ocean on one side or the Atlantic Ocean on the other side or mountains or something that is hard to reproduce. When you play this golf course or a golf course like this, I mean, it’s different. You feel like you’re a million miles away from any given place and you can’t look in any direction and not have a great vista.
quotes.context: In a longer on‑camera explanation, Pete outlines what makes great courses and why this self‑contained, mountainous site fits that criterion.

quotes.text: You start thinking about this golf course… I don’t see how you get 18 holes any better. Now, nine holes ain’t better than this nine over here. I really don’t.
quotes.context: Talking informally with James D. and Max, Pete expresses his belief that the front nine they’ve built is as good as any nine holes anywhere.

appearances.role: Golf course architect and on‑camera commentator
appearances.description: Identified on screen in multiple inset interview shots (older man, white hair, glasses, light bucket hat). He provides unscripted, conversational commentary about what makes a great golf course, the uniqueness of the West Virginia topography, the coal‑mine integration, the finishing of holes (especially #4 and #18), and the dramatic nature of the property. His written welcome letter is also shown on screen near the end.

quotes.text: All great golf courses, you know, what makes a great golf course is usually you have the Pacific Ocean on one side or the Atlantic Ocean on the other side or a mountain or something that it's hard to reproduce.
quotes.context: Pete Dye begins explaining his philosophy of what makes a great golf course while aerial and ground‑level shots show the West Virginia hills and fairways.

quotes.text: Well, the general topography right through here, you know, of this part of the country, you can't reproduce it.
quotes.context: Continuing his design philosophy, Dye contrasts the unique hills of north‑central West Virginia with flatter regions where architects must manufacture features.

quotes.text: So when you play this golf course or a golf course like this, I mean, it's different. You feel like you're a million miles away from any given place and you can't look at any direction and not have a great vista.
quotes.context: Over panoramic fairway and valley shots, Dye emphasizes the immersive, remote feeling and constant vistas that define the Pete Dye Golf Club experience.

quotes.text: Now every hole here has a distinctive look to it and a great background.
quotes.context: Dye describes how each hole at the club has its own visual identity and backdrop, as the film shows varied holes framed by hills, rock faces, and trees.

quotes.text: Out here, I assure you that every golf hole we have out here, we have a terrific variation in strategy, short, long, different.
quotes.context: He underscores the strategic diversity of the routing while viewers see a mix of par‑3s, par‑4s, and par‑5s across hilly terrain.

quotes.text: Most golf courses, you come into an area like the biggest this, it's hard to get it done to what really looks like a finished product. And now we're getting closer and closer where it looks like every hole has been finished.
quotes.context: Discussing the concept of a “finished” golf course, Dye praises the ongoing refinement work at Pete Dye Golf Club as visuals show polished greens and fairways.

quotes.text: Four has been sitting there as a great golf hole for almost four years. And now that we're starting to make it look more like a finished hole, everybody starts to see it.
quotes.context: He uses the 4th hole as an example of a hole that has always been strategically strong but is only now being visually completed.

quotes.text: A golf course is like Augusta National. It's a great golf course, and it has a certain atmosphere. But just going in Magnolia Drive, it's impressive.
quotes.context: Dye compares the importance of the arrival experience at Augusta National to the entrance road at Pete Dye Golf Club.

quotes.text: Well, I assure you that the drive coming into this golf course is equally, if not more so, impressive.
quotes.context: He boldly claims that the drive from Smith Chapel into Pete Dye Golf Club rivals or surpasses Augusta’s Magnolia Lane in impact.

quotes.text: You start right out at the Smith Chapel and make that turn, and then when you start back that road, you feel, the minute you make that turn to go back there, that you're going to some place. You're going to something.
quotes.context: Dye describes the emotional build‑up of the entrance drive as aerial shots show the valley and routing leading toward the clubhouse.

quotes.text: I don't think I've ever seen any more dramatic than this piece of property. I don't know how else you can say it. There isn't anything more dramatic than this.
quotes.context: Standing figuratively on the property in his mind’s eye, Dye emphasizes the unmatched drama of the site as the camera shows steep hills and quarry‑like features.

quotes.text: You know, to stand on 4T, it's about as dramatic a thing as you're going to see, that mountain behind 4.
quotes.context: He singles out the 4th tee as one of the most visually dramatic spots on the course, with a mountain backdrop.

quotes.text: We've got one little deal to fix on this front nine, and that's it. You can go to hell and gone. You're going to have a long time. You've got all the room in the world to play. I don't see how you can get 18 holes any better now. Put that down in quotation. I really mean that.
quotes.context: In a candid, emphatic moment, Dye asserts that once a minor issue is resolved, the 18‑hole course will be as good as any, urging that his statement be quoted.

quotes.text: The historical significance of the land, first as an Indian campground then as a site of coal mining operations, is combined with the spectacular terrain of the West Virginia hills. This has allowed me to create 18 of the most exciting and memorable holes that I have ever built on one course.
quotes.context: Pete Dye’s written and spoken statement appears near the end of the film, superimposed over course and coal imagery, summarizing the site’s history and his design achievement.

quotes.text: I'm very proud of this golf course and I believe it will be recognized as one of the great golf courses of the world. This golf course is a very special place.
quotes.context: Continuing his closing statement, Dye expresses pride and predicts global recognition for the Pete Dye Golf Club.

appearances.description: Primary voice explaining the construction, equipment, and long‑term golf design; appears on camera multiple times in a light blue shirt and cap holding a microphone.

quotes.text: It's our intention here to clean the creek bed, and then someday when we're playing golf here we'll have a beautiful river in the middle of our golf course.
quotes.context: On‑camera narration at Simpson Creek, explaining why they are dredging and reshaping the channel.

quotes.text: It's almost like a highway under the water.
quotes.context: Describing the solid sandstone creek bottom that allows heavy end loaders to drive directly in the stream without getting stuck.

quotes.text: We've had a pretty steep bank here, and this will soften it and make it mowable. Whereas before we probably would have had to put a vine so that we wouldn't have to attempt to mow the bank.
quotes.context: Explaining how reusing dredged silt on the hillside will change maintenance from groundcover vines to mowable turf.

quotes.text: We're standing on the landing area of the 18th green of the Pete Dye Golf Club alongside Simpson Creek. We have a project going on today in the bed of the creek where there's a natural ford in the river.
quotes.context: Introducing the August 9 work to blast out a shallow hump at a natural ford so the river will be consistently deep for boating and aesthetics.

appearances.description: Mentioned as “Jimmy” in the context of Pete Dye telling him he wouldn’t come back until certain features were fixed; not seen on camera here.

Younger LaRosa who, in the September 28, 1990 on‑course segment, stands in a striped golf shirt with a microphone, introduces Pete and the crew (Sheriff DeAnna, Mike Delaney, Tom Hansberry, Woody Podesta, Keith “Sparky” Sparkman), and asks Pete for comments about the course.

appearances.role: Project co-manager and on-camera host introducing staff
appearances.description: Younger/middle-aged man in white dress shirt and patterned tie, often standing beside Pete on the dirt fairways. He introduces the professional staff and crew (Bill, Gary, Keith, Mike, Jim Jamieson) and frames the project as entering a new phase.

quotes.text: This is Bill Stines. Bill joined us this year from The Honors Course in Ooltewah, Tennessee, another one of Pete's great designs. Bill's position now is head golf professional.
quotes.context: Jimmy begins introducing the key professional staff to camera, starting with head pro Bill Stines.

quotes.text: Gary Grandstaff has been with us for how many years now, Gary? Fifteen. Fifteen? It's been a long time, but Gary has been involved in about every blade of grass that's been grown here. He's our superintendent. He's also in charge of construction on the back nine.
quotes.context: Jimmy highlights superintendent Gary Grandstaff’s long tenure and central role in both construction and conditioning.

quotes.text: Keith Sparkman, Sparky, has been with us about as many years, I think. Fifteen and a half. Keith has been principally Pete's right-hand man on the project. He's been involved in turning over about every blade of dirt 10 or 12 times.
quotes.context: Jimmy introduces Keith “Sparky” Sparkman as Pete’s right-hand man in the dirt-moving and shaping work.

quotes.text: Mike Langkau joined us last year… This is his third season… Mike's been here also. He's worked with Pete as a shaper and has been very busy shaping this back nine and getting it in a condition where we can get finished.
quotes.context: Jimmy introduces shaper Mike Langkau and notes his role in finishing the back nine, including prior work on other Pete Dye courses.

quotes.text: Jim Jamieson's been with us for two years. This is his second year. Jim's been a world-class golfer, a world-class gentleman. He's our director of golf and a good friend. He certainly adds a lot to the atmosphere that we're trying to develop here. He's one hell of an emcee and a great dancer.
quotes.context: Jimmy introduces Director of Golf Jim Jamieson, praising both his professional pedigree and his personality.

appearances.description: Middle‑aged man in tan/light blazer and tie who welcomes guests, explains the 17‑year journey, introduces staff (Gary Grandstaff, Billy, Bill Steines, etc.), describes membership strategy, and formally introduces Alice and Pete Dye. He also tells the detailed “Miracle Mountain” and gob‑pile stories and asks Pete about trips and construction dates.

quotes.text: He told me years ago, I said, Pete, don’t kid me, how good is it going to be? He said, you really want to know? And I said, yes. He said, well, you know, Jim, you’re not smart enough to see it. He said, I can see it. I said, you can’t.
quotes.context: Opening anecdote in Jimmy’s welcome speech, illustrating Pete’s blunt confidence in his design vision when the course was still only an idea.

quotes.text: When I think of all the memories that I had with him, I can see now what he saw then. And I think the man’s a genius. He spent all the money I had and all the money I could borrow. But I wouldn’t have had it any other way. Thank you, Pete. Thank you. Thank you.
quotes.context: Conclusion of Jimmy’s tribute, publicly thanking Pete for his vision and the sacrifices made to build the club.

appearances.role: President & CEO, Pete Dye Golf Club; developer
appearances.description: Appears in sit‑down and on‑green interviews. Describes building the course with his father, the coal‑mining heritage, construction photos, and expresses gratitude for staff, volunteers, state, and coal industry support.

quotes.text: Oh, I think we have. The crowds have been overwhelming. The support we’ve gotten from our staff and the volunteers and the state and the coal industry has just been wonderful. It’s just overwhelming, actually.
quotes.context: Live interview with Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram when asked if the event has exceeded his expectations.
