quotes.text: That’s some of our men and equipment and some of Pete’s men there, building number two just down below the green and as we’re building up the fairway.
quotes.context: Describing archival construction photos of the 2nd hole during a feature on the course’s building phase.

quotes.text: Yeah, we certainly are. We’re fortunate that Pete took that perspective on the project, and it truly has added to the environment that we have here.
quotes.context: Response to Brian Anderson, affirming that preserving coal‑mining remnants enhanced the course’s character.

quotes.text: It was just eight short months ago that we decided to have this tournament, and I’m humbled and overwhelmed by your support. Just take one second to look around and look at everyone that has supported this event and we applaud you for supporting this thing. Thank you.
quotes.context: Speech during the trophy ceremony, reflecting on how quickly the event came together and thanking all supporters.

quotes.text: DA, I’m not sure what course you were playing, and we are going to do a blood test right after this, okay? But congratulations, an honor for us to bestow this award onto you.
quotes.context: Light‑hearted remark as he presents the heavy coal‑cart trophy to D.A. Points after his 23‑under performance.

appearances.description: Younger man compared to James D., appears explaining tee construction, fertilizer applications, and walking viewers through progress on multiple holes.

quotes.text: This is the first day that we’re putting fertilizer on the greens. They’ve been cut once, they’ve been limed twice, and as you can see up on 7 green there, he’s fertilizing number 7.
quotes.context: Jimmy explains spring agronomy work while Louie films a fertilizer rig on the 7th green.

appearances.description: Appears in later 1991 segments (e.g., April 27 and May 25) as a middle‑aged man in a white golf shirt and glasses, standing with Monsignor O’Reilly and later with Gary. He explains the construction of the 3rd green, bunker strategy, and pin positions with Keith Sparkman, and later discusses drainage problems and fixes on #7 green.

quotes.text: Monsignor here wouldn’t be any problem for him because he’s terrific in the sand. He’s just like Chi‑Chi Rodriguez. He’s got a good short game. All old timers start with a short game.
quotes.context: Light‑hearted comment while explaining the deep front bunker on #3 green to Monsignor O’Reilly.

quotes.text: The lake that you see in the back is man‑made. Pete saw that lake the first day he walked out here in his imagination. He thought that should be a lake.
quotes.context: Explaining how Pete Dye envisioned the #3 lake from his first site visit, underscoring Dye’s design eye.

appearances.role: James D.’s son and project co-manager
appearances.description: Referred to as “Jim,” “Jimmy,” or “James Jay.” Appears in group introductions on the 4th fairway with PB Dye and others; also referenced when Louie jokes about never charging him.

Younger than James D., appears in light button‑down shirts on hillsides and fairways, sometimes holding a mic. Explains specific holes, earthmoving operations, and technical aspects like coal seam removal and creek cleaning.

Younger than James D., appears in construction scenes in light shirts and slacks, sometimes with a mic. He explains fairway grading, mine‑portal routing between 6 and 7, and later gives progress updates (e.g., on 17th green seeding). He also appears in group shots and with Pete Dye on holes.
Mentioned by name when discussing bunker sand replacement and compaction; credited with trying to firm up the sand despite soft conditions from rain.
Identified by Louis (“Good morning, Gary”) on Oct 3 at #9. Explains lime and rock phosphate, irrigation, drain risers, and seeding schedule. Seen in work clothes on the course.

appearances.role: Golf course superintendent and construction lead on back nine
appearances.description: Course superintendent, described by Jimmy as having been there 15 years and involved with “about every blade of grass,” in charge of back-nine construction and conditioning. Visually likely one of the older crew in work clothes, but not uniquely identifiable in a single frame.

Named and introduced by Jimmy as “Gary Grandstaff,” the superintendent who finalized construction, installed irrigation, and “grew the course in.” Pete later thanks “Gary” for putting up with him. Not clearly seen speaking on camera in this excerpt.

Identified by name in the greens-construction segment. Explains sand sourcing, green construction, seeding strategy, and points out Pete Dye associate Keith Sparkman. Also seen working alongside crew, raking and grooving greens.

quotes.text: Louis, what you see the guys doing out there now is we’re just grooving the green for the seed bed. It lets the seed fall down in little grooves that those rakes are making, and then we’ll take a hand roller after we seed, close the grooves back up, and that’s the preparation for our seed bed.
quotes.context: On #1 green, explaining the hand‑grooving process as workers rake the sand mix before seeding.

quotes.text: This green is a culmination of not only 12 years, but since I’ve been involved here at the Pete Dye Golf Club, we started searching for sand a little over a year and a half ago, and James D. managed to find some down in Worthington, which is about 12 miles away.
quotes.context: Detailing the sourcing and importance of the sand used in the first green’s construction.

quotes.text: Louie, another individual who’s been involved here, not only on this green site, but the remaining green sites here at the club, Keith Sparkman. He’s worked for Pete Dye, came up here from finishing the greens on Kiawah Island, where next year’s Ryder Cup will be held. He’s the man that put the finishing touches on this green site.
quotes.context: Introducing Pete Dye’s shaper and crediting him for the final contours of the greens.

appearances.description: Seen on construction sites in work clothes, often with dogs nearby. Gives detailed explanations of green construction, drainage layers, and bunker finishing, and identifies crew members by name.

quotes.text: Five days ago we thought we had a drainage problem… The only problem we really had that had us stumped for a few days was a compacted sand layer. We’ve taken care of that problem… Everything’s straightened out and we’re back on an even schedule and ready to get it done.
quotes.context: Standing on seven green, Gary explains how they diagnosed and fixed a drainage issue using a subsoiler.

quotes.text: Louie, if you remember about five days ago, we had you out to take a picture of some film here of Seven with the sprinklers running with standing water. We thought we had a drainage problem…
quotes.context: Reminding Louie of earlier footage as he documents the resolution of the drainage issue on seven green.

quotes.text: You go in there after you walk off the back of number six after you made birdie, and on through the mine portal, and that brings you out over on seven tee.
quotes.context: Explaining the unique routing through a mine portal between six green and seven tee.

appearances.description: Named multiple times (“Gary Grandstaff”) and appears on‑camera in work clothes. He explains green construction profiles (sand/peat mix, gravel, drain tile), erosion netting, sod logistics, and drainage troubleshooting on greens #6 and #7. He also narrates a panoramic pan from the second landing area of #5, pointing out stone walls, bunkers, and his dog Bogart.

quotes.text: Five days ago we thought we had a drainage problem, and we had water puddling on the surface of the green… We brought the subsoiler in and literally did a subsoil profile of the entire green every 24 inches, turned the water back on, and it works fine. So the only problem we really had that had us stumped for a few days was a compacted sand layer, and we’ve taken care of that problem.
quotes.context: Explaining how they diagnosed and fixed a drainage issue on #7 green by subsoiling the sand layer.

quotes.text: This is the eighth green now this year that we’ve put mix on… We’re presently out of sand this year. This is kind of our critical green since we’re finishing up here on six to see if we need any more sand or if we have a sufficient amount on here now.
quotes.context: Describing the status of #6 green construction and sand inventory in November 1990.

appearances.description: Seen and heard extensively on the construction sites explaining green construction, sand sourcing, seeding, sod work, erosion netting, and bridge progress. Often referred to simply as “Gary” and explicitly called “the superintendent.”

quotes.text: It's October the 9th. It's a Tuesday. It's been overcast off and on mist today. We're going to go ahead and try and get number one green planted. It's our first green here on the golf course.
quotes.context: On‑site introduction to the first green construction sequence, standing on the hillside above the unfinished green.

quotes.text: You can see the pink flags, Louie. They're for the green area, which will be planted in Pencross bentgrass that has a blue‑green color. And then outside of those, the inner circle of pink flags, will be planted in Pen Eagle bentgrass, which is what we presently have on number one fairway and as all the fairways will be planted.
quotes.context: Explaining the layout and turf varieties for the first green and surrounding fairway while walking and raking on the sand surface.

quotes.text: This green is a combination of not only 12 years, but since I've been involved here at the Pete Dye Golf Club, we started searching for sand a little over a year and a half ago. And James D. managed to find some down in Worthington, which is about 12 miles away.
quotes.context: Reflecting on the long planning horizon and crediting James D. LaRosa for sourcing suitable sand as the camera shows the shaped green cavity.

quotes.text: Well, Louie, it's a beautiful day. What else can I tell you? It's almost November, I guess. And I'm going to say here probably towards the end of the day we ought to have this one finished up and moving over to two. These guys really know what they're doing. They set that bridge there probably in about an hour this morning. Just really incredible.
quotes.context: Standing near the Simpson Creek bridge installation, commenting on the crew’s efficiency and the plan to move on to the next bridge.

quotes.text: Louie, what you see the guys doing out there now is we're just grooving the green for the seed bed. It lets the seed fall down in little grooves that those rakes are making. Then we'll take a hand roller after we seed, close the grooves back up, and that's preparation for our seed bed.
quotes.context: Describing the manual grooving process on the first green as workers rake parallel lines across the sand surface.

quotes.text: Right now we're just seeding down the rough mix, which is a combination of blue and ryegrass. The wind kind of has us at a standstill for the bentgrass. You can see the little flags blowing like crazy and we can't put it down. Bentgrass is real light. There's about 9 million seeds to the pound. It's just too windy right now.
quotes.context: Explaining why they are delaying bentgrass seeding on the first green due to high winds while proceeding with rough seeding.

quotes.text: Hi, Louie. It's November the third. I guess it's Indian summer this time of year. I don't know, but it sure as heck is nice. It's better weather than Florida is having right now. Just perfect. Probably about 75 degrees. We're getting a little sod down here on the ninth green.
quotes.context: Opening his November 3 update while showing crews sodding the steep bunkers around the ninth green.

quotes.text: You can see the guys carrying around ladders. The bunker faces are so steep that we have to use ladders in order to climb up and start the first few rows of sod until we can get it down far enough where they can reach and not tear anything up.
quotes.context: Describing the practical challenges of sodding very steep bunker faces at the ninth green.

quotes.text: Off to the right of the green or to the left of the dozer is an area that we sodded, and above the sod we used erosion netting, which is our first use of that material here at the Pete Dye Golf Club. We've really had a tremendous amount of success with it. As for cost savings, it cuts our seeding and planting and stabilization of bank areas by about 60%, so you'll be seeing more of that as we go along.
quotes.context: Explaining the introduction and benefits of erosion netting on banks near the sixth green and a front bunker.

appearances.role: Course superintendent, Pete Dye Golf Club
appearances.description: On-camera guest interviewed about course preparation; explains bunker sand replacement, firmness goals, and working with PGA Tour officials.

quotes.text: These guys are really good. Everything that we’ve done to try and stop them really hasn’t worked.
quotes.context: On-course interview about course setup and how soft conditions and wide fairways have allowed low scoring despite efforts to firm up bunkers and greens.

quotes.text: The fairways are wide. I haven’t seen but three players in the rough, I believe, and watching them hit into the greens has just been phenomenal. There aren’t any long putts, and making birdie out there is pretty easy, as you can tell by the scores.
quotes.context: Continuing his explanation of how the course is playing during the Nationwide Tour event.

quotes.text: We’ve learned an awful lot on course preparation from the PGA themselves, and they helped us tremendously to prepare the golf course, and it’s been fun.
quotes.context: Explaining collaboration with PGA Tour officials in setting up Pete Dye Golf Club for the Nationwide Tour event.

appearances.description: Interviewed on-course about course conditioning and setup for the Nationwide Tour event; explains bunker work and cooperation with PGA officials.

quotes.text: These guys are really good. Everything that we’ve done to try and stop them really hasn’t worked.
quotes.context: On-course interview about course setup and how soft conditions and wide fairways have allowed low scoring despite efforts to firm up bunkers and greens.

quotes.text: The fairways are wide. I haven’t seen but three players in the rough, I believe, and watching them hit into the greens has just been phenomenal. There aren’t any long putts, and making birdie out there is pretty easy, as you can tell by the scores.
quotes.context: Continuing his explanation of how the course is playing during the Nationwide Tour event.

quotes.text: We’ve learned an awful lot on course preparation from the PGA themselves, and they helped us tremendously to prepare the golf course, and it’s been fun.
quotes.context: Explaining collaboration with PGA Tour officials in setting up Pete Dye Golf Club for the Nationwide Tour event.

appearances.description: Identifies himself as “Harris Holt.” Teases Louie about not setting up the jelly and butter correctly, rearranges the buffet, and later explains to camera what’s happening with the carts and the grand opening round.

quotes.text: First of all, you didn’t get this done correctly, so therefore Ann and I had to come over and do it.
quotes.context: Teasing Louie about the jelly and butter arrangement at the breakfast table while he and Ann Hart fix it.

quotes.text: All these people, all these carts are for the members and their guests who are teeing off, and this is the grand opening day for the Pete Dye Golf Club.
quotes.context: Explaining the scene of many carts and players assembling for the grand opening round on the back nine.

appearances.description: Mentioned by James D. in other segments; here he is referenced in the office/lunch context but not clearly seen in this excerpt.

Named and greeted (“Here comes Harris… Hi Harris… Say hi camera.”). Acts as Louie’s on‑camera associate, narrating parts of the dinner and dignitaries. May also be the professional narrator voice in some course‑overview segments.

quotes.text: This is going to be the dinner in honor of the Pete Dye Golf Club opening up. We can see a few dignitaries down through there. Among them is Alan Mollohan…
quotes.context: Narration as the camera pans across the lakeside banquet setup and crowd before the opening dinner.

appearances.description: Named multiple times (“That’s Mr. Harris Holt my assistant and I’m Louie Ellis”). Provides structured narration on holes 1–6, explains fairway and green construction, and introduces segments (“We’re standing on the tee at number five…”).

quotes.text: Louie, the view that you have in your lens right now is the landing area of number two. You can see how the fairways have just come up so magnificently, and I remember when the bank was sodded. Now, if somebody had seen that before and after, then they would really understand why it had to be sodded.
quotes.context: Standing near #2, describing the transformation of the fairway and the decision to sod a steep bank.

quotes.text: Number five is a dogleg right, the only true par five on the course. There just isn’t anybody who can get to this hole in two.
quotes.context: On the #5 tee, explaining the strategy and difficulty of the hole while showing early grass growth.

quotes.text: Louie, we’re standing up here to the right of number seven green, looking back toward Four Lake. And the purpose of this is to show the number five hole from an elevated view. You can see how green everything is. I was out here last week, and everything was all still brown.
quotes.context: From an elevated vantage, illustrating how quickly the seeded fairways have greened up.

quotes.text: We’re standing on the number five tee on the number one fairway, and what you see now is actually in the final stages of construction. There’s four tees right in the foreground—the one we’re standing on and then three more. And the number one tee will be the men that you can see working in the foreground, and they’re putting in the number one tee. The composition of this tee and the sand that’s on it came from a glacier deposit about 20 miles from here in Worthington.
quotes.context: Explaining the tee construction and sand sourcing on October 17, 1990.

appearances.description: Identified by name in the transcript. Appears hitting approach shots on number five and narrating where the tees, landing areas, and green are, often with Louie filming.

Named multiple times (“Harris Holt says we’re 102 yards from the green… pretty exacting guy”; “How about the mic in front of me, Harris?”). He is off‑camera most of the time, occasionally warned about footing (“Watch it, Harris”). He provides precise yardages and likely holds the mic at one point.

Frequently identified by name (“Mr. Harris Holt is at the mic”). He provides polished, hole‑by‑hole descriptions of fairways, greens, bunkers, and construction details, often directing Louie where to point the camera. He is seen on camera in a white golf shirt with glasses, holding a microphone while describing views along Simpson Creek and the tees of #2 and #5.

quotes.text: Absolutely, Louie, the view that you have in your lens right now is the landing area of number two. You can see how the fairways have just come up so magnificently, and I remember when the bank was sodded.
quotes.context: Harris takes over narration to describe the landing area of #2 and recall earlier sod work on the banks.

quotes.text: Now, if somebody had seen that before and after, then they would really understand why it had to be sodded.
quotes.context: Explaining the dramatic visual difference sod made on steep banks along the fairway.

quotes.text: You can see the little bridge in the background that sort of looks like the bridge on the River Kwai.
quotes.context: Pointing out a distinctive small bridge over Simpson Creek near #2, using a movie reference to describe it.

quotes.text: Louie, we’re standing on the tee at number five. Simpson Creek’s out here on the right. You can see how the grass is starting to come up. If you point your camera down very, very low, you can see…
quotes.context: Orienting the viewer at #5 tee and directing Louie to capture close‑up detail of the emerging turf along Simpson Creek.

quotes.text: These guys really know what they’re doing. They set that bridge there probably in about an hour this morning. It’s just really incredible.
quotes.context: Admiring the efficiency of the crew installing the Simpson Creek bridge at #10.

appearances.description: Appears around the bridge installations, giving detailed explanations of how the bridge is bolted down, its weight (21 tons), and design/engineering details. Also helps narrate town/building history and prompts others to speak.

quotes.text: This is the bridge that's being put in, crossing Simpson Creek at number 10. First half of it is up. The second half is just about underway. Louis, if you'll… well, you don't have to swing around yet, but I can see the bridge now being backed up. It's a beautiful day for picture taking. What's a beautiful day for anything? That stone wall on the other side of Simpson Creek is outstanding.
quotes.context: Standing near Simpson Creek, Harris narrates the status of the #10 bridge installation and admires the stone wall across the creek.

quotes.text: That section is 21 tons. That knowledge came to us through the courtesy of Gary Grandstaff.
quotes.context: While explaining the crane operation and counterbalancing, Harris notes the weight of the bridge section and credits Gary for the information.

quotes.text: Louie, the picture you're taking now is the building where James D. was born.
quotes.context: Identifying the run‑down brick building in Glen Elk as James D. LaRosa’s birthplace during the town tour.

quotes.text: You can see up there at the top of the building, Louie, it says Martin and La Rosa, and the building was built in 1920. When the Home Hotel was in its heyday, it was a nice establishment.
quotes.context: Pointing out the “Martin & LaRosa” inscription and date on the former Home Hotel building, tying it to the LaRosa family history.

appearances.role: On-site assistant / explainer, later professional narrator voice
appearances.description: Identified by name while standing in bunkers and explaining cinder playability and fertilizer/topsoil operations. Also appears in later segments as the calm, technical voice describing seeding, Chapel Valley mix, and wildlife.

quotes.text: We like the wildlife down here. There's squirrel and wild turkey and deer, groundhog, fox… and then there's some dark ducks on the river too on Simpson Creek.
quotes.context: Commenting on the wildlife already inhabiting the course while overlooking the 18th and 10th fairways.

appearances.description: Off‑camera assistant referenced by name when asked to turn on the lake fountain; not clearly seen but heard or mentioned.
Louie’s wife, referenced in Louie’s opening and closing thanks (“from Louie and Nancy”). She is not clearly seen speaking but is part of the couple gifting the tape.
Not clearly visible in this reel but named by Louie as the recipient of DiMaggio’s autographed poster. Also appears on the Ellis Productions title card photo.
Not seen speaking, but Louie and James D. address her directly in absentia, thanking her for support and “making it more available to us.”
Not seen clearly but repeatedly thanked as Louie’s essential helper and for making coffee; referenced in jokes about laundry and hats.
Mentioned by name in the sign‑off (“He and his wife, Nancy, say hello to you”). Not seen clearly on camera in this excerpt but acknowledged as part of the filming effort.
Not seen, but repeatedly addressed by Louie and James D. as proof that Louie was on-site “since 3 o’clock.”
Named by Jimmy in the Sept 28, 1990 segment as “Keith… we call him Sparky, that’s in charge of the construction of it.” Seen in a green hat doing final shaping and seeding work.

Referred to as “Keith Sparkman, Sparky,” Pete’s right-hand man who has “turned over about every blade of dirt 10 or 12 times.” Likely one of the men in work shorts/T-shirt or blue golf shirt, but not uniquely isolated visually.

Identified repeatedly in narration as “old Sparky,” “one of the greatest people as far as greens are concerned.” Visually he appears in work clothes on dozers and on slopes, but often camera is too distant for a clear face. His work is the shaped greens, banks, and seeded slopes around 11, 16, 18.

appearances.role: Pete Dye’s greens shaper and contour specialist
appearances.description: Referred to as “Sparky” and “Keith Sparkman,” seen working a small Smithco machine around greens (#4, #6, #7, #3). Others describe him as Pete Dye’s trusted greens man who travels from course to course, putting final contour on greens and bunker faces. Rumored in the narration to have an MD degree.

Named repeatedly as the man who finished the contours on the first and ninth greens and will “come over with his Smithco” to blend edges. Seen on camera working on green and bunker faces, though not speaking.
Primary Golf Channel play‑by‑play voice for the Nationwide Tour broadcast. Narrates hole‑by‑hole action, introduces segments, and closes the show (“For our entire crew, I’m Brian Anderson…”).

quotes.text: Top 60 and ties make the cut on the Nationwide Tour. You’re going to be a little nervous for a while if you’re sitting on one under par because it is on the verge of going to two.
quotes.context: Explaining the cut‑line dynamics late in the second round as many players still have holes left to play.

appearances.description: Golf Channel play‑by‑play announcer in the booth, introducing the telecast, course, and storylines, and steering between live shots, highlights, and commercial breaks.

quotes.text: Pete Dye, it’s the only golf course Pete Dye has designed that bears his name. He believes this is his best work, best collection of holes that he’s ever designed.
quotes.context: Booth introduction of Pete Dye Golf Club’s uniqueness and Dye’s own view of the course.

quotes.text: We’ll be thinking of Jeff Julian today on the day that he passes away. Of course it grabbed Bruce Edwards during the Masters earlier this year. So Jeff Julian passes away of ALS today, July 15th.
quotes.context: Somber moment in the booth as they acknowledge the death of former PGA Tour player Jeff Julian from ALS and reflect on his courage.

appearances.description: Primary on‑air host in the broadcast booth, introduces the telecast, interviews Jimmy LaRosa, and frames the event’s significance and competitive storylines.

quotes.text: It seems that the whole state of West Virginia has really gotten behind this event and good for them.
quotes.context: In the booth early in the broadcast, commenting on strong community and statewide support for the inaugural event.

quotes.text: And I think the key there is when you get the developer, the La Rosa family behind the event like they have, you know it’s going to be a first‑class event and it definitely is.
quotes.context: On‑air analysis crediting the LaRosa family’s backing as central to the event’s quality and organization.

quotes.text: You know, it’s interesting that I was talking to Pete Dye earlier this week, and he said the La Rosa family kind of wanted to cover up the coal aspect, you know, the coal mining aspect, but he demanded that you keep it, and now aren’t you glad you did?
quotes.context: Booth commentary to Jimmy LaRosa while showing coal‑heritage structures on the course.

quotes.text: Pete Dye wasn’t expecting 19‑under par at the turn on Saturday. You think he’s having trouble sleeping right now?
quotes.context: Reacting to D.A. Points reaching 19‑under during the third round, highlighting how low the scoring is relative to Dye’s expectations.

appearances.description: Primary booth host for the Golf Channel’s Nationwide Tour coverage, introducing segments, recapping scores, and interviewing guests.

Called “Jerry” and “Fultzy,” he follows groups including D.A. Points and Gavin Coles, giving lie descriptions, club selections, and anecdotal color (e.g., softball jokes, intimidation in teed‑up competitions).

quotes.text: D.A. has hit every fairway, every green. He’s made every makeable putt. You know, it doesn’t matter how tough a golf course is designed, when you can hit it where you’re aiming and the ball is stopping there.
quotes.context: On‑course reporter summarizing D.A. Points’ dominant performance during his run of four straight birdies.

appearances.description: Golf Channel on‑course reporter following specific groups (Imada/Gow/Gump), offering lie descriptions, yardages, and anecdotal context; also hosts a light “Teed Up” trivia segment.

quotes.text: He’s inventing new ugly ways to make par today, and he’s going to have his work cut out for him here.
quotes.context: On‑course description of Paul Gow scrambling from deep rough and false fronts to save par, highlighting his gritty but erratic play.

appearances.role: On‑course reporter / trophy‑presentation host, The Golf Channel
appearances.description: Leads the trophy ceremony, introduces sponsors and state officials, interviews Jimmy LaRosa and D.A. Points on the green.

quotes.text: Well this tournament received an advance billing and some pre‑tournament hype like no other tournament we’ve experienced, and I got to tell you, everyone on hand, you not only lived up to it, you exceeded it on every front.
quotes.context: Opening remarks at the trophy presentation on the 18th green, addressing organizers, sponsors, and fans.

quotes.text: Congratulations to a world class event and a world class facility and world class support from your state.
quotes.context: Continuation of his trophy‑ceremony praise, emphasizing the quality of the event, club, and state backing.

quotes.text: Number one on the money list, number one in your hearts and the winner of the inaugural Pete Dye West Virginia Classic, D.A. Points.
quotes.context: Ceremonial sign‑off at the end of the trophy presentation, summarizing Points’ status and win.

appearances.description: Ground-level reporter (“Foltzy”) providing yardages, lie descriptions, and player interviews; also hosts the “Teed Up Cup” trivia segment.

quotes.text: He’s not missing the center of the hole. Yes, pouring them in. His fourth birdie, and again back-to-back birdies. He did it at two and three, and now at five and six.
quotes.context: On-course commentary as D.A. Points continues a hot putting streak to climb the leaderboard.

quotes.text: Well, it’s better to be convinced than to be correct, they say. I think both is better.
quotes.context: Commenting on Gavin Coles taking extra time over a short putt at the 5th, reflecting on the psychology of reading putts.

appearances.role: Nationwide Tour player and tournament leader
appearances.description: Featured extensively as the runaway leader at the Pete Dye West Virginia Classic. Announcers highlight his bogey‑free streak, precise distance control, and recent form (62 in Chicago, 66 in Pennsylvania, win in Scranton). Shown hitting fairways and greens, making multiple birdies, and putting confidently.
Tour player highlighted for shooting an opening 65 (-7), described as surprising given expectations that the course would play tougher.
Featured extensively in highlights and live coverage as the runaway leader and eventual inaugural champion. Gives a full winner’s interview and interacts warmly with fans and volunteers.

quotes.text: Well, obviously it was a fantastic week for me. It started out better than I’ve started any other golf tournament in my life. And I battled myself a little bit today, but fortunately I calmed myself down and got back into my game plan and finished strong, shooting three under the back nine.
quotes.context: Winner’s interview with Jerry Foltz, reflecting on his performance and mental approach in the final round.

quotes.text: When you’re playing well, you get good breaks. And today actually I could say that I got some good breaks and I got some not so good breaks, so today was pretty even. Earlier in the week was a little bit more favorable.
quotes.context: Answering a question about the many fortunate bounces he received during the week.

quotes.text: All in all, West Virginia, this is my first time here and everybody’s been really, really supportive and everybody’s been so nice and a lot of fun, and hopefully this won’t be my last time here.
quotes.context: Closing part of his winner’s interview, praising local hospitality and expressing desire to return.

appearances.description: Professional golfer and central figure in the tournament narrative; shoots 65 in round one and contends for his second win of the year, repeatedly shown hitting approaches and putts and discussed as a key storyline.

Chasing D.A. Points at −8 to −9, described as hungry to get back to the PGA Tour after finishing 151st on the money list. Shown hitting solid irons, making birdies, and missing a few putts; commentators praise his consistency and attitude.
Described as one of the hottest players on tour, firing a 66; appears in highlights making birdie putts.
Contender with several key putts shown in highlights and leaderboards.
Player at -7 who is repeatedly shown on holes 14–17, including key par saves and birdie attempts; discussed as a recent graduate from the tour seeking a return to the PGA Tour.

Two‑time Nationwide Tour winner from Australia/New Zealand. Shown repeatedly on par‑3s and par‑5s, often frustrated by missed putts. Announcers reference his wins at the Jacobs Creek Open and New Zealand PGA and his struggles on the PGA Tour.
Repeatedly featured on 7, 8, 10; frustrated by missed putts. Announcers note his down‑under wins and poor PGA Tour season.
Australian player nicknamed “the angry ant,” featured on several shots (notably at the 5th and 6th) and in on-course commentary about his unique swing technique.
Australian pro featured on par-5 5th and 6th holes with wedge and putt sequences; discussed as normally a very fast player.
Referred to as “Val” and “Val Skinner,” she provides yardages, green‑reading notes, and comments on players like Darron Stiles, Troy Matteson, and Bobby Kalinowski from ground level.
LPGA veteran serving as on‑course commentator, especially with groups including Hunter Haas, Franklin Langham, and others; comments on wind, green speeds, and shot options.

quotes.text: We sit in sort of a valley where this old coal mining operation was, and that wind swirls around a lot here. It looks to me like he misjudged the wind right there.
quotes.context: On‑course analysis after Brad Ott’s tee shot at the par‑3 13th goes long right, illustrating how the reclaimed mine topography affects play.

appearances.description: LPGA veteran providing on-course analysis, especially on approach shots, green complexes, and player mindset; often addressed as “Val.”

quotes.text: Oh yeah, the theme here is bump, bite, and roll—and please get close to the hole. How many elephants are in this green, guys? Six.
quotes.context: Describing the extremely contoured 17th green at Pete Dye Golf Club as Darron Stiles faces a difficult third shot.

appearances.role: Nationwide Tour player and early clubhouse leader
appearances.description: Mentioned as having posted −11 with a 67 earlier in the day, chasing D.A. Points. Not clearly seen speaking but appears in leaderboard graphics.
Highlighted for four straight top‑10s and playing his way onto the tour via Monday qualifiers and sponsor exemptions; shown making birdies at 14, 15, and 16.
Young star with multiple recent top-10s; co-leads at -11, featured in multiple highlight packages (birdies at 6, 8, 9, 12, etc.).

appearances.role: Nationwide Tour player and course‑record holder
appearances.description: Referenced as having set the course record with a 63 in the first round, followed by a 71. Appears in leaderboard graphics.
Shown on leaderboards and in highlights as an early leader and contender in the event.
24-year-old pro who shoots a course-record 63; co-leads at -11 and is tracked closely on the leaderboard and in highlights.
Appears in Orlando studio updates, delivering Open Championship and BC Open leaderboards. Identified by name in the transcript (“Hi everybody, Mike Ritz reporting.”).
Host of Golf Central update segments from Orlando, delivering Open Championship and other PGA Tour scoreboard updates and news (including Jeff Julian’s passing).
Host in Orlando studio delivering Golf Central updates on the Open Championship (voiceover over leaderboard graphics).

Introduced by James D. as “my right‑hand man on the job.” Appears in construction segments (bridge move, site work) and is greeted in the dogs‑and‑cats section. Not clearly heard speaking in the provided transcript.
Named as holding a cup of water to acclimate fish; appears at pond edge helping pour lake water into bags.
Construction superintendent praised after a successful dynamite blast; appears briefly on camera after removing his hat and glasses.

appearances.role: Friend/PR voice; technical and humorous commentary
appearances.description: Appears multiple times: explains sand/peat/fertilizer topmix and why trucks avoid the green, jokes about PR, and is thanked for still photos. Also appears taking stills of James D. and the dogs.
Named on‑course by Louie (“That’s Sam Oliverio getting ready to hit. He fell backwards but that’s okay.”).
Appears with James D. near opening, joking about the opening date and being shown blacktopping work.

Named repeatedly as Pete Dye’s “eyes, ears, arms, and legs.” Appears on No. 16 and No. 11 greens with John and cousin Andrew, often quiet but acknowledged as the man who forms the holes with machinery.
Seen on‑site in work clothes and hard hat, referenced repeatedly as “Max” or “Maxie,” described as Pete’s on‑site superintendent who carries out Dye’s instructions and shapes fairways.
Appears in construction meetings with Pete and the LaRosas, often in work clothes and cap. He is referenced by name in narration and occasionally speaks about dirt‑moving and teamwork.
Golf Channel analyst in the booth with Anderson, providing technical and strategic commentary on Pete Dye’s design, course conditions, scoring, and player decisions.

quotes.text: When you get the developer, the LaRosa family, behind the event like they have, you know it’s going to be a first‑class event, and it definitely is.
quotes.context: In‑booth discussion early in the telecast about why this inaugural Nationwide Tour event is already viewed as a premier stop.

quotes.text: It’s very unusual that you would ever give a golf course architect that kind of time and have that kind of patience. But they were in no hurry. They wanted this thing to be special. They wanted Pete Dye to be able to do exactly what he wanted to do with every hole.
quotes.context: Extended commentary on the LaRosa family’s long‑term commitment and Pete Dye’s creative freedom in building the course.

quotes.text: Interesting, this golf course, as you mentioned, on an old coal mining operation. And the owners, the LaRosa family, wanted to kind of lose the coal mining aspect, but Pete Dye says, he said, ‘Keep it in there. I want to see the coal gobs and I want to see…’ It is very unique and really, really picturesque and visually stimulating.
quotes.context: Booth discussion while cameras show coal tipples and shafts behind the 18th green, explaining Dye’s insistence on preserving mining features.

quotes.text: All the par threes are over par on the scoring average. It won’t be just today. It’s going to be every day. These are some really good par threes.
quotes.context: Commentary on the difficulty of the par‑3s at Pete Dye Golf Club after several players struggle at the 4th and 13th.

quotes.text: You can definitely make a mistake with a sand wedge trying to pitch it, but with this putter you’re going to be somewhere around the hole.
quotes.context: Booth analysis as Franklin Langham elects to putt from the fringe at the 9th instead of chipping, emphasizing smart short‑game strategy.

appearances.description: On-air analyst in the booth with Brian Anderson, providing technical commentary on swings, strategy, and course design; often addressed as “Kurt.”

quotes.text: It’s a great venue. Pete Dye did a really good job with the design of this golf course. I think he thinks it may be one of his best. And you knew with the developers, the LaRosa family behind it, it was going to be a first class event.
quotes.context: Booth discussion early in second-round coverage, reflecting on day-one impressions and the quality of Pete Dye Golf Club and its ownership.

quotes.text: It’s kind of funny, you know, you come to a new venue like this, and of course it’s a Pete Dye golf course. You know, the expectations are what get these guys. I heard some guys say it’ll be, you know, 18 under. And then I heard somebody else say, ‘Oh, I think even par is good. I’d like to get it at even par and sit on it.’
quotes.context: Booth commentary on how players misjudged scoring expectations at a new Pete Dye venue, given soft conditions and low scores.

quotes.text: These guys are good, and it’s all right to see a few birdies. The USGA has a serious infatuation with even par, all right? That was made pretty clear this year.
quotes.context: Discussion about scoring philosophy in professional golf, contrasting the Nationwide Tour event with the recent U.S. Open at Shinnecock.

appearances.role: Director of Golf, former tour player
appearances.description: Described by Jimmy as a world-class golfer and gentleman, Director of Golf, former PGA Tour player and former golf director at The Greenbrier. Likely one of the taller, athletic men in golf attire, but not clearly isolated in the provided visual notes.

Former PGA Tour player introduced formally at the club. Seen and heard explaining his playing record, ambitions for celebrity/tour events, and the format/handicap rules for the opening member play day. Also filmed swinging on course.

quotes.text: Thank you very much. I’d like to thank the La Rosa family for the opportunity to be here and to be a part of the Pete Dye Golf Club. This is quite a unique piece of property. If the back nine is anything like the front nine, this should be so special.
quotes.context: Acceptance remarks after being introduced as Director of Golf.

quotes.text: Hopefully, we’re going to bring in celebrity events, maybe a tour event. We’d certainly like to host a Ryder Cup, a Curtis Cup, or a Walker Cup.
quotes.context: Outlining long‑term aspirations for high‑profile competitions at the club.

quotes.text: From now on, from this day forth, you’ll have two sets of handicaps… You’ll have your traveling handicap… and then you’re also going to have a membership handicap. And that goes in a little black book. Right, Louie?
quotes.context: Explaining the club’s handicap system to members at the opening play day, with a joking aside to Louie Ellis.

quotes.text: So Doc might be a 15 in Morgantown, but he’ll probably be 11 here. So don’t give me all these phony handicaps.
quotes.context: Light‑hearted warning to members about inflating handicaps for the new course.

quotes.text: We’ve put a lot of love and tender care into the project, and we want it to be special for you all. So you all have to help us take care of the place out there.
quotes.context: Course‑care appeal before members head out to play, noting unfinished sod and fragile new turf.

appearances.description: Young competitor at −6 to −7, shown hitting approaches on 14, 16, and 17. Announcers note his age (26) and that he’s trying to make a run at the Pete Dye West Virginia Classic.
Player shown making birdies on 17 and 18; his round is corrected to a 66; discussed as a strong starter at -5/-6.

Featured on holes 16, 17, and 18. Shown saving par from tough lies, then making a double bogey at 18 after a difficult third and fourth shot. Identified as a past Nationwide Tour champion and former PGA Tour player from Clemson.
Highlighted for excellent iron play and birdie chances, especially at the 14th and 15th holes.
Georgia Tech All‑American, shown hitting into the par‑3 4th and putting on 4 and 8. Announcers note he’s a two‑time All‑America selection playing his first year on tour.
Shown making birdies at 14 and 16; described as a 24‑year‑old Georgia Tech grad; part of the -3 group on the leaderboard.
Shown multiple times (holes 6, 7, 8, 9) hitting bunker shots, long putts, and saving par; described as a winner earlier in the year and trying to get to -2.
Featured on the 10th hole with a difficult birdie putt and described as having an up-and-down day.
Featured extensively in the Imada/Gow/Gump group; shown hitting irons, recovery shots, and putts; described as a two‑time Nationwide winner and strong iron player.
Contender shown multiple times on the 9th and 10th holes; commentators compare his yardages and lies to Paul Gow’s.

appearances.role: Nationwide Tour player / storyline of near‑misses
appearances.description: Australian player highlighted for three playoff losses and being the only top‑10 money‑list player without a win; shown repeatedly scrambling for pars and birdies, including at 2, 4, 6, 8; described as “inventing new ugly ways to make par.”
Australian pro repeatedly shown hitting approaches and putts, often from the 9th and 10th holes; discussed for his playoff record and birdie chances.
Discussed as the youngest ever to qualify for the PGA Tour at 17; shown at the drivable par‑4 12th and par‑5 15th; commentary notes his struggles, mononucleosis, and attempts to rebuild his game.
Young pro shown saving par on 18 and making the turn at even par; his grouping and hopes for a big week are mentioned.

Professional-looking man in golf attire (not distinctly isolated visually here) introduced by Jimmy as having joined from The Honors Course in Ooltewah, Tennessee, now serving as head golf professional.

Named on camera as “Bill Stein” (mispronunciation of Stines). He’s introduced as a friend of Jimmy LaRosa, “just here to help out,” and is thanked while Ellis plugs “video provided by Ellis Productions.”
Appears in the later group on the 4th fairway when James D. introduces “P.B. Dye” as having made a major contribution. Younger man in golf/construction attire.

Appears in a later group shot on the 4th fairway, introduced as having made a major contribution to construction. Dressed in golf/work clothes, standing with James D., Jimmy, Drew Pearson, and others.
Unseen voice delivering the repeated biographical and contextual narration about 1978, the fading mining industry, and Jim Compton’s life and vision.

quotes.text: In 1978, as the family backbones of the mining industry faded, the area was forced to reinvent itself.
quotes.context: Opening line of the narration, repeated multiple times over black frames, family footage, and mining imagery to establish the economic backdrop for the Pete Dye Golf Club story.

quotes.text: A leader in this effort was Jim Compton.
quotes.context: Introduces Jim Compton as the central figure in the region’s reinvention, over both black frames and later over family and community visuals.

quotes.text: Jim was born and raised in Clarksburg.
quotes.context: Begins Jim Compton’s biographical sketch, tying him to a specific West Virginia hometown.

quotes.text: He left to pursue a career in marketing and advertising.
quotes.context: Explains Jim’s departure from West Virginia to build professional skills that he will later bring back to the region.

quotes.text: After 20 years, Jim returned as a skilled marketing and advertising professional.
quotes.context: Marks Jim’s return to his home state, now equipped to help lead economic and land‑use reinvention.

quotes.text: Jim realized that corporate West Virginia would need an upscale meeting place,
quotes.context: Introduces the core insight that will eventually lead to the creation of a high‑end club and course.

quotes.text: and he began to think of ways to develop some of the land that was available to him
quotes.context: Connects Jim’s vision to specific family land resources, moving from idea to potential project.

quotes.text: as his family began to sell off their holdings.
quotes.context: Explains the urgency and context for development: family land is being divested, prompting Jim to act.

quotes.text: Archival footage from Pete Dye Golf Club story (1978-2004).
quotes.context: Meta‑narration labeling the visuals as archival material spanning the years of the Pete Dye Golf Club project, reinforcing the historical nature of the footage.

quotes.text: Thank you for watching
quotes.context: Closing line over black, suggesting this assembly may have been used as a standalone historical piece or temp cut within the larger documentary.

name: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

appearances.role: Primary on‑camera host and technical narrator of the construction tour
appearances.description: Older man with short white/gray hair, wearing a plaid button‑down shirt and blue pants in some shots, often holding a microphone. He walks the site, stands on tees and in bunkers, and speaks directly to Pete Dye, to cameraman Louie, and to “Jim” (James D. LaRosa). He gives detailed yardages, design intent, and construction status.

quotes.text: There goes the boss of all bosses. Boy, he worked the hell out of me today. There he goes. There he goes. Good old Jim.
quotes.context: As James D. LaRosa drives away with his family and dogs in their vehicle (“dogmobile”), the narrator affectionately comments on Jim’s demanding leadership on site.

quotes.text: This wall that you’re looking at now is about 70 feet high, and then the trees above it are 60 to 70 feet high, so there’s about a 120 to 30 foot wall here on the right‑hand side, vertical.
quotes.context: Standing in the 8th‑hole canyon bunker, the narrator quantifies the dramatic strip‑mine high wall and tree height to convey the scale of the hole to Pete.

quotes.text: We’ve stripped this overburden off the coal at Pete’s direction and created this Grand Canyon feeling, which if a person slices a ball, he’s going to be down here on the second shot.
quotes.context: Explaining how Pete Dye’s design choice to expose the coal seam and high wall shapes both the aesthetics and the playing penalty on the 8th hole.

quotes.text: The fairway is 40 yards wide, and then the bunker will be 60 yards wide, so we’ve got over 100 yards before you get to the ditch, and I guess we’re going to leave it open.
quotes.context: Discussing the 8th hole’s fairway, massive bunker, and an open drainage ditch along the coal seam, while asking Pete to confirm where to terminate the ditch.

quotes.text: As you can see, there’s a couple of levels here that drop off. But the feeling you get in here, you can hit the ball and the ball’s going to be in here somewhere. You can’t lose it on the second shot. I think that’s something pretty unusual for a second shot.
quotes.context: From about 45 yards short of the 8th green, the narrator explains the approach contouring and why it’s designed so that second shots remain visible and playable.

quotes.text: Number two, you have to drive over Simpson Creek, get to a landing spot. You can eat off as much as you want, but the more you eat off, the farther it is back to the hole and the less club you have to use. If you don’t want to eat off too much, then you have more club that you would have to use to get to the green.
quotes.context: Explaining the risk‑reward tee shot on the dogleg‑left 2nd hole from an elevated vantage, with Simpson Creek guarding the landing area.

quotes.text: It has taken a lot of thought to put number eight together, as you can see up through there. This is the last hole on the front side that they have done anything with.
quotes.context: Standing in the 8th fairway, the narrator reflects on the design complexity and notes that #8 is the last front‑nine hole under active construction at that time.

quotes.text: You remember your good friend, Louie Ellis, who we call Cecil B. DeMille here in Clarksburg, who does all our filming. He wanted to say hello to you and let you know that he did this photography and walked over this ground with his bad hip because it was for Pete Dye.
quotes.context: The narrator introduces Louie’s sign‑off to Pete, praising Louie’s dedication in filming the rugged site despite physical discomfort.

quotes.text: This little chunk of stone out there looks like some sort of a golf club. This is at the end of number two.
quotes.context: Pointing out a distinctive rock feature near the end of hole #2 that visually resembles a golf club, adding character to the landscape.

appearances.description: Named repeatedly as the person who prepared and displayed the food. Male voice giving a detailed guided tour of the buffet (“Uncle Louis? Let me tell you what we have…”). Also appears in kitchen and buffet setup shots in white shirt and apron.

quotes.text: Uncle Louis? Yes sir? Let me tell you what we have. We'll start down the line. This is a little Mexican variety here. We've got everything from the piccata sauce all the way down to some jalapeno peppers.
quotes.context: Chef/host begins a guided tour of the buffet, addressing Louie as “Uncle Louis.”

quotes.text: We've got a hollowed out crusty pumpernickel with a spinach dip.
quotes.context: Describing one of the centerpiece appetizer presentations on the cold table.

quotes.text: And since you haven't eaten today, we better give you a little bit.
quotes.context: Playfully offering Louie some food while showing the bread bowl and dip.

quotes.text: And then we've got three different kinds of cheese here. We've got jalapeno pepper cheese, a sharp cheese, and a mozzarella. And then you've got some baby Lorraine Swiss with Kobe Longhorn. And then we have some gorgeous shrimp. Probably the prettiest shrimp I've seen in years.
quotes.context: Continuing the detailed rundown of the cold table and seafood display.

quotes.text: Well, actually, this is one loaf of bread. That's one loaf of very, very good crusty bread. It was given to Mr. La Rosa by a fellow countryman of his, Frank T. Chargerot, of Country Club Bakery in Fairmont.
quotes.context: Explaining the origin and significance of the large braided loaf presented at the party.

quotes.text: Only at Easter would that happen.
quotes.context: Responding jokingly when Louie asks if there’s an egg in each hump of the braided bread.

name: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

appearances.description: Provides polished, broadcast-quality narration that introduces Clarksburg, Pete Dye, the Burning Embers Resort concept, and then walks through the strategy and yardages of all 18 holes. Voice is distinct from Pete Dye and James D. LaRosa and never appears on camera.

quotes.text: The Pete Dye Golf Club in Clarksburg, West Virginia, is the first phase of the planned Burning Embers Resort and Conference Center. It is the result of a visionary developer, James La Rosa, who acquired the land and sought out the famous architect.
quotes.context: Opening narration over title cards and early course imagery, introducing the project’s scope and crediting the developer.

quotes.text: Ten years of labor and commitment by the developer and designer have been invested in this project.
quotes.context: Narration over aerial and scenic shots, emphasizing the long timeline and partnership between LaRosa and Dye.

quotes.text: Number six is a 341-yard par four straightaway. The shortest par four on the course. A very tight driving hole demanding a long accurate tee shot to the right of the walled stream bed which separates the fairway from the rough. This creates an interesting second shot. A coal mine portal is visible behind the green. Upon finishing this hole, the player must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to get to the seventh tee.
quotes.context: Part of the hole-by-hole strategic narration, highlighting the integration of the site’s coal mining heritage into the playing experience.

quotes.text: Number ten is a spectacular hole. It is a 450-yard par four dogleg right. A string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive, and a 25-foot vertical waterfall protects the green on the right. Number ten is an ominous-looking hole, but is very fair with a bailout area to the left of the green.
quotes.context: Describing the dramatic visual and strategic elements of the 10th hole during the back-nine overview.

quotes.text: Number eighteen, the magnificent 18th. Beautiful, breathtaking. A 450-yard par four from an elevated tee across Simpson Creek which borders the left side of the fairway. The player's second shot will be hit from an ample landing area but he will need to be on the left side to be open to the green. The right side of the fairway is a contoured hillside allowing up to 30,000 spectators. Provision for 30,000 spectators evokes dreams of major tournaments.
quotes.context: Final hole description, explicitly linking the design of the 18th to aspirations of hosting major tournaments.

quotes.text: The vision of James La Rosa and genius of Pete Dye have combined to create a unique opportunity in central West Virginia. Thanks for letting us share this excitement with you.
quotes.context: Closing statement of the film, summarizing the partnership and inviting viewers to share in the project’s excitement.

appearances.description: Delivers the polished, promotional narration describing the club’s mission, West Virginia’s advantages, the yardages and strategies of each hole, and the LaRosa family’s vision. The voice is distinct from Pete Dye’s and from the brief on‑camera LaRosa ID shot, suggesting a hired narrator (possibly Harris Holt, but not explicitly identified in this footage).

quotes.text: The course will play from 5,200 yards to 7,100 yards depending on which set of tees are played, thus ensuring a pleasurable experience for golfers of all levels.
quotes.context: The narrator introduces the course’s flexibility and target audience before beginning the detailed hole‑by‑hole tour.

quotes.text: Number six is a 341‑yard par‑4 straightaway. The shortest par‑4 on the course. A very tight driving hole demanding a long accurate tee shot to the right of the walled stream bed which separates the fairway from the rough. This creates an interesting second shot. A coal mine portal is visible behind the green. Upon finishing this hole, the player must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to get to the seventh tee.
quotes.context: During the front‑nine tour, the narrator highlights the unique integration of a real coal mine into the playing sequence between holes 6 and 7.

quotes.text: Number ten is a spectacular hole. It is a 450‑yard par‑4 dogleg right. A string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive and a 25‑foot vertical waterfall protects the green on the right. Number ten is an ominous looking hole but is very fair with a bailout area to the left of the green.
quotes.context: The narrator describes the dramatic visual and strategic elements of the 10th hole, emphasizing coal cars and a waterfall as defining features.

quotes.text: Thirteen is a 185‑yard par‑3. The view on this hole is breathtaking. Mother Nature at her greatest. It is somewhat similar to the famous Redan hole in Scotland.
quotes.context: In the back‑nine tour, the narrator compares the 13th hole to the classic Redan template, underscoring the course’s links‑style inspirations.

quotes.text: The magnificent eighteen, beautiful, breathtaking. A 450‑yard par‑4 from an elevated tee across Simpson Creek which borders the left side of the fairway. The player's second shot will be hit from an ample landing area but he will need to be on the left side to be open to the green. The right side of the fairway is a contoured hillside allowing up to 30,000 spectators.
quotes.context: The narrator presents the 18th as a championship‑caliber finishing hole with built‑in spectator mounding, over visuals of the valley and creek.

quotes.text: The Pete Dye Golf Club hopes you have enjoyed these few moments with us and we invite you to share in a lifetime of unparalleled golfing experience.
quotes.context: The narrator delivers the film’s closing invitation over logo and scenic shots, positioning the club as a place for enduring, high‑level golf experiences.

appearances.role: Master of ceremonies and Executive Director of the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce
appearances.description: Middle‑aged man in a brown/tan jacket and glasses at the podium for much of the evening. He welcomes guests, runs the program, delivers the humorous ‘Healthy West Virginia’ skim‑milk toast with “Walt,” presents the Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year award, and later presents the Ambassador of the Year.

quotes.text: In West Virginia, small business is big business. Within the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce, some 70 percent of our membership is made up of small business entities.
quotes.context: Introducing the Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year award.

quotes.text: Our small business that we’re recognizing this evening was started in a small kitchen in Glen Elk by a fine lady preparing a delicious product and selling it in her corner grocery store… Over the past three generations, the family production of this product has increased from the canning of some 65 bushels of peppers in two weeks to a production level of over 600 bushels in one day.
quotes.context: Building suspense before revealing Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers as the Small Business of the Year.

quotes.text: Well, I felt so, and that is why I have selected for the 1995 Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year, Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers.
quotes.context: Announcing the winner of the Small Business of the Year award.

quotes.text: In West Virginia, small business contributes heavily to the success of our so‑called large businesses—our banks, our utilities, our schools, and yes, even our hospitals.
quotes.context: Explaining why the Chamber is honoring a small business and how small firms underpin larger institutions.

quotes.text: This award is given to the person that best exemplifies the Chamber’s role in the community. This person is visible at all or most functions in which the Chamber participates… it takes a person dedicated to their Chamber and to their community and to give their time and efforts to represent the Chamber at these particular events.
quotes.context: Describing the criteria for the Ambassador of the Year award before announcing John Lowe.

appearances.role: Keynote speaker – health‑care reform and managed care expert
appearances.description: Physician and former President/CEO of Park Nicollet Medical Center in Minneapolis; at the time Vice President of Clinical Services for SunHealth. Gives a long, slide‑supported talk on U.S. health‑care history, costs, managed care, and Minnesota’s integrated system. Speaks in a measured, explanatory style.

quotes.text: Health care historically is not a problem. Health care is becoming a problem because of the changes in our society. It is not a group of bad people, but there are problems that are occurring in health care and we must admit they’re there.
quotes.context: Early in his keynote, explaining that systemic issues, not bad actors, are driving the health‑care crisis.

quotes.text: We as a society created the American health care system, and we as a society will restructure it in ways that will make it work better in the future.
quotes.context: Framing his analysis of U.S. health care as the product of collective societal choices.

quotes.text: Car manufacturers need systems to create cost‑effective quality automobiles… Health providers need systems to create cost‑effective quality health care. We cannot continue to play like we have health care, quality health care, in non‑systems.
quotes.context: Using a systems analogy to argue for integrated health‑care delivery.

quotes.text: I am absolutely confident that 10 to 15 years from now, American medicine is going to be the envy of every country in the world… because we are living in a time of dramatic change that will lead to very great opportunities in health care.
quotes.context: Closing his keynote with an optimistic prediction about American health care’s future.

quotes.text: It is your health care system. It is your community. You have the right to set it up the way you wish. I hope that you choose to create your own system. I hope you do not wish to be controlled by New York City or L.A. or some other place.
quotes.context: Final exhortation to the local business and civic audience to build their own integrated health‑care systems.

appearances.description: Primary voice in many segments, often opening with “recognize as being built by J.D. La Rosa.” Appears in red cardigan with tie and sunglasses, and also in more casual shirts. Walks viewers through tipple, tracks, fairways, and clubhouse/tee siting.

quotes.text: What you see here must be approved by Pete Dye. Now when he comes in to look at this, if it's not what he wants, then he informs Max on how to change it.
quotes.context: Describing Max Robinson’s role and Pete Dye’s final authority over shaping on the 12th hole.

quotes.text: Max had just told us that Pete Dye is one of the top three designers in the United States, or in the world probably… and that he probably has more golf courses in the top 100 than any architect.
quotes.context: On the 12th fairway, relaying Max Robinson’s assessment of Pete Dye’s stature and global work.

quotes.text: Personally, he's number one in my books, but when it comes from people like Max, who's been on hundreds of golf courses working with him, should know.
quotes.context: Continuing his praise of Pete Dye’s design legacy while standing on the 12th landing area.

quotes.text: This tipple was actually standing here when we first came onto this project back in 1978 or ’79… and now we're going to incorporate it into the background and the theme of this golf course.
quotes.context: Explaining the decision to preserve and reuse the old coal tipple as a central visual element along the 10th hole.

appearances.description: Older Italian‑American man from Florida who delivers long, animated monologues about stealing coal, Irish cops, undertaker work, the FBI’s Italian founder, and George Washington being ‘Italian.’ He is addressed as Frank and is clearly a central storyteller at the luncheon.

quotes.text: We lived in tenement houses… We used to go to the freight trains and steal coal… We done nothing to hurt anybody. We done it because of necessity. That's a hell of a word, isn't it?
quotes.context: Telling childhood stories about growing up poor in New York and stealing coal out of necessity.

quotes.text: Who do you think founded the FBI, the Federal Bureau of Investigation? The Italians. You bet your sweet platoon. His name was Charles Bonaparte… People don't realize that. They call us all mafiosos. I wish we were mafiosos. We'd straighten this country out one, two, three.
quotes.context: Continuing his humorous monologue about Italian pride and American institutions.

quotes.text: You don't learn that in school. You learn that on the street.
quotes.context: Explaining his rough upbringing and street smarts while telling stories about judges and fights.

appearances.role: Interior designer of the guest house
appearances.description: Introduced as being from Harrison County/Clarksburg, living in Atlanta. She designed the interior colors, window treatments, furniture, and most selections in the new guest house and gives a functional tour of a typical guest room and bath.

quotes.text: This is for individual guests. They can enter from an exterior door so they have private access.
quotes.context: Explaining the purpose and layout of a guest room in the new guest house during the interior tour.

quotes.text: There’s an armoire that they got at Friendly Furniture in Fairmont. It’s cherry. It’s to put their things in there. Later on, they can put a TV in there if they’d like.
quotes.context: Detailing the furnishings and future‑proofing of the guest room storage during the tour.

quotes.text: The prints that you see were from a guest, I’m sorry, a member that Jim LaRosa… she offered to let us use those. All the pictures that you’ll see in the bedrooms are part of this private collection.
quotes.context: Describing the origin of the golf‑themed artwork in the bedrooms and emphasizing member contributions.

appearances.description: Unseen professional voiceover artist delivering the scripted lines that describe the Pete Dye Golf Club and tie it into CBS Morning programming.

quotes.text: In America, most golf courses look like this.
quotes.context: Opening line of the bumper, setting up a contrast between typical golf courses and Pete Dye Golf Club.

quotes.text: But here at the Pete Dye Golf Club in Clarksburg, West Virginia, we built a golf course around abandoned coal mine lands.
quotes.context: Narration over shots of the course and a mine entrance, emphasizing the reclaimed coal mine setting.

quotes.text: Weekdays, we tee off with CBS because we know there's more to this morning.
quotes.context: Closing line tying the Pete Dye Golf Club story into CBS Morning branding as the CBS graphic fills the screen.

name: Unidentified Glen Elk narrator (likely a LaRosa/Ellis contemporary)

appearances.description: Male voice and presence in car, often in red jacket, who drives through Glen Elk, points out buildings (Morocco Club, Elk Bridge, Lee Hotel, Parson Hotel, Coca‑Cola bottling works), and interviews local shop owners like the Oliverios.

quotes.text: Louis, the picture you’re taking now is the building where James D. was born. Did you say that was a house one time? Well, it looks like it’s been a building, but I mean, Jim’s family lived there when Glen Elk wasn’t as large as it is now.
quotes.context: Driving through Glen Elk, pointing out James D.’s birthplace and explaining that it served as a family home when the neighborhood was smaller.

quotes.text: Papa Jim La Rosa had this building built many years ago. It’s called the Elk Bridge. And it was his favorite thing. He liked it very much. And he wanted us to stay in the building as long as we could.
quotes.context: Street‑side explanation of the Elk Bridge building in Glen Elk, just before its demolition.

quotes.text: I used to work on the truck in the summertime. Made $15 a week and didn’t know what I was going to do with all the money. How about that?
quotes.context: Driving past the old Coca‑Cola bottling works in Glen Elk, recalling summer work as a youth.

name: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)

appearances.role: Storyteller about Morocco Club & Home Hotel
appearances.description: Provides first‑person reminiscences about the Morocco Club, Home Hotel, and playing in a band called the Rhythm Boys; jokes about being “only the fiddler” when the place was raided. Likely a local friend of the LaRosa family, possibly Harris or another elder, but not definitively matchable to a named character.

quotes.text: Hello Louie. Here's what we have left of Jim's building after Lou carelessly was doing some work with a blowtorch. I don't know how old this building is, but it has fond memories for me because the old Morocco Club used to be there.
quotes.context: Standing in front of the damaged Morocco Club building, introducing its history and hinting at a recent fire or damage incident.

quotes.text: I used to have a little band called the Rhythm Boys, and we were over here playing dances, and at that time, you know, we did a little… I guess the places did a little illegal. Today it's legal, but then it wasn't, to sell a little whiskey, and they raided the Home Hotel. Well, that wasn't so bad, but they're going to take the band too. I had a hell of a time convincing these cops that, hell, I'm only the fiddler around here… They let me go, but that's the last time I ever played over here. A lot of fun, though. A lot of memories.
quotes.context: Recounting a humorous and nostalgic story about playing music at the Home Hotel when it was raided for illegal liquor.

quotes.text: Louie, this is James A. La Rosa's home. This is where all the La Rosas grew up. Jim is very proud of this. He's done a lot of work on the inside in order to keep the home livable. It's a very impressive home. The lions are out front there as if to stand guard to keep anybody inside from harm. I've been in the home when young Jim lived there. I'm sure it's very dear to Jim's heart.
quotes.context: Voiceover while the camera shows James A. LaRosa’s family home and its lion statues, emphasizing its emotional importance to the LaRosa family.

appearances.description: Middle‑aged man with gray hair and glasses, often in a dark polo or striped rugby‑style shirt, delivering formal remarks about the 15‑year project, reading the club’s mission, and recognizing Pete Dye, God/Mother Nature, and his father. Seen both indoors at breakfast/meeting and outdoors at ceremonies.

quotes.text: We are going to turn this golf club into one of the great golf environments of the world. With your help, and certainly with the help of management, we will be able to achieve our objectives.
quotes.context: Formal breakfast speech outlining the club’s mission and ambitions to members and early stakeholders.

quotes.text: It’s to establish an international golf club of unparalleled stature and coveted membership. To create a tribute to the genius of the architect. To be the foundation of an environment built on the values and tradition of the game. And to be a model of success for all clubs through the successful management of the club and its properties.
quotes.context: Reading the written mission and objectives of Pete Dye Golf Club to assembled members.

appearances.description: Referred to in third person as the man who had the Elk Bridge building constructed and whose birthplace in Glen Elk is repeatedly pointed out. Also appears in construction-era segments discussing leveling a hill for commercial development and later in golf-course context.

quotes.text: We’ve been here nearly three years, and we’re about finished. And I wanted to capture this look for posterity. It was a wild idea that Jimmy Joe and I had, and we decided to go ahead and do it, level this hill, and create a commercial piece of ground that the people of the greater Clarksburg area would always have available to them in the future.
quotes.context: On the leveled hilltop after the blasting project, explaining the purpose of the large earthmoving job Louie has been filming.

quotes.text: Louie, I want to thank you for taking these pictures of our operation. We’ll always appreciate having them, I know, for our own historical reasons. But you’ve been a friend down through the years, and what you’re doing now is awfully nice.
quotes.context: On the leveled hilltop, expressing gratitude to Louie for documenting the project.

appearances.description: Appears on camera in a branded golf shirt delivering an official welcome on behalf of the state, framing the tournament as important to West Virginia’s image and economic diversification.

quotes.text: West Virginia was built on a foundation of coal mining and now is a place of diverse economic resources including biometrics, research, tourism, and superb outdoor opportunities.
quotes.context: On‑camera gubernatorial welcome tying the state’s mining past to its diversified present and outdoor appeal as he introduces the tournament.

quotes.text: Once a coal mining site, this beautiful golf course exemplifies West Virginia by providing a welcome destination for experienced tour professionals and tourists alike.
quotes.context: Still in his opening address, explaining the transformation of the Pete Dye Golf Club property from mine site to golf destination.

appearances.description: On‑air analyst alongside Brian Anderson, comments on course design, scoring conditions, Pete Dye’s reaction, and the event’s status on the Nationwide Tour.

quotes.text: Apologies to Pete Dye. It’s a beautiful golf course. But if you give these guys, the quality of this field, soft, windless conditions, they are going to take advantage. That’s all there is to it.
quotes.context: Analyst explanation for the unexpectedly low scores, defending the design while attributing scoring to conditions and field strength.

quotes.text: This golf course is legendary in these parts. It’s a beautiful Pete Dye golf course. And secondly, we’ve got a bunch of good players out there right now, and they’re out there to see them.
quotes.context: Discussing why galleries are so large despite rain—local reverence for the course and the quality of the field.

name: Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Joe LaRosa)

appearances.description: Appears with his wife; described as one‑third of the organization along with James D. LaRosa. Speaks about hosting staff and friends at the Christmas party.

quotes.text: We're having our staff and all of our friends in today who we've worked with all year and we're just getting started.
quotes.context: Jimmy explains the purpose of the Christmas party while on camera with his wife.

appearances.description: Older man in light shirt who gives a long, heartfelt roll‑call of friends from California, Florida, North Carolina, etc., and thanks Jimmy LaRosa. He is repeatedly addressed as ‘Sheriff’ and stands at the luncheon and later in the game room. Not a law‑enforcement official here, just a nickname.

quotes.text: Well, today I've got all my good friends. I've got all my good friends from California, Florida. I've got James Gwynn from California. I've got Vito Verga from Miami, Florida, along with his brother, Ron Verga… My good friend Whitey Bridges… my good friend Benny Lorenzo, who has Lorenzo's Restaurant in North Miami… Anytime when you get good friends, you can make friends like this and break bread, it's great.
quotes.context: Standing at the luncheon, giving a roll‑call of out‑of‑town friends and thanking Jimmy LaRosa.

appearances.description: Introduced explicitly as “the great Willie Mosconi.” Older man in vest and shirt, holding a cue, giving a short on‑camera comment about playing the Sheriff 35 years earlier and then performing shots in the pool room. The Sheriff and James D. both refer to him by name.

quotes.text: No, I'm here because I played this guy 35 years ago. And he's no different now than he was 35 years ago. He's still a stat in the chair. He never slowed down.
quotes.context: On‑camera comment after being introduced as ‘the great Willie Mosconi,’ referring to playing the Sheriff decades earlier.

appearances.role: President and CEO, United Hospital Center
appearances.description: Hospital executive who comes to the podium to thank the Chamber for honoring health‑care providers and to introduce keynote speaker Dr. Charles Jacobson. Middle‑aged man in suit, speaking on behalf of the two local hospitals.

quotes.text: First of all, on behalf of the two hospitals in town, we want to thank you for honoring us. But I think the board members and our physicians would agree with me that it’s important, if you’re going to recognize somebody in the healthcare system, the most important group to recognize is the people across the street right now who are working on all of those units… without them, the rest of us couldn’t get anything done.
