quotes.context: United Hospital Center CEO Bruce Carter thanking the Chamber for honoring health‑care providers and emphasizing frontline staff.

appearances.role: Grandson; appears in TV news segment
appearances.description: Identified in the Wheeling College TV7 sports piece as “James J. La Rosa, grandson of the man the field is dedicated to,” who speaks on camera about Father Acker and the facility.

quotes.text: Father Acker’s persistence, that was one. Two is a feeling that we have for the school… after visiting the site a couple times and just getting involved, I think, basically with the people here.
quotes.context: In the TV7 sports piece, James J. explains why the LaRosa family invested in Wheeling College’s fields, citing Father Acker’s persistence and their connection to the school community.

appearances.description: Voice heard asking, “Are you sure you want to retire?”, likely in a later‑life interview or family conversation, used as a motif over various archival images.

quotes.text: Are you sure you want to retire?
quotes.context: A conversational line, likely from a later interview or family recording, used repeatedly over various archival images to frame the story as a choice between retirement and embarking on a major new project.

appearances.description: Introduces himself from Fairmont; later filmed hitting shots (“Nice swing, Raymond”).

quotes.text: I had my brother here last Sunday… he’s been all over this country, and he happened to make one remark… He said, ‘This is the mountain masterpiece,’ and that sums it up in one sentence.
quotes.context: Self‑introduction during the member roll‑call, quoting his brother’s reaction to the course.

appearances.description: Identified by Harris at the opening dinner (“Among them is Alan Mollihan… I’ve already interviewed him and his son.”).

quotes.text: First of all, we’re very proud of Jimmy La Rosa and his commitment to this golf course. I know he’s worked on it for years, and it’s been something that’s been very meaningful to him for a long period of time. It just feels very nice to see it coming to fruition. He deserves it.
quotes.context: On‑camera interview at the lakeside event, praising Jimmy LaRosa’s perseverance and the realization of his vision.

appearances.description: Introduces himself on camera as “Tom Murray, world‑class bagpiper from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania,” part of the Syria Highlanders pipe band.

quotes.text: My name’s Tom Murray. I’m a world‑class bagpiper from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Glad to be here.
quotes.context: Self‑introduction of the lead piper from the Syria Highlanders pipe band before the evening ceremony.

appearances.description: Introduces himself as pipe sergeant of the Syria Highlanders pipe band.

quotes.text: This is a small representation of the Syria Highlanders pipe band from Pittsburgh. We’re a national‑renowned band. We’ve won competitions all over the country.
quotes.context: Pipe sergeant introducing the band and its credentials on camera.

appearances.description: Elder LaRosa patriarch who immigrated from Italy, fought in both the Italian and U.S. armies, and built businesses in hotels, restaurants, real estate, and coal. In his 90s here, he gives a concise life story on camera.

quotes.text: My name is James LaRosa Sr. I came to this country in 1907. I’ve also been engaged in business, hotels, restaurants, real estate, the coal business the last 30 years. I’m very glad to be in this country. I served in the Italian Army from 1911 to 1912. I also served in the American United States War in 1918. I’m very happy for what I did, and happy that the people love me 9 out of 10. I would say I’m very glad that I love the country, I love the people, and I was born in 1891. I’m now 91 years old, and I’m happy to be here.
quotes.context: Formal sit‑down interview segment with Papa Jim and Virgil, filmed outdoors near one of their coal operations.

appearances.role: Son of Papa Jim / coal and tipple operator
appearances.description: Papa Jim’s youngest son. Speaks about working with his father in the coal business since 1950 and shows one of their coal tipple operations.

quotes.text: Well, I’ve been working with my father since he got into the coal business in 1950. We’ve had a close association with one another, and we continue to do work. And he’s now reached the age of 90 years, and he’s still going strong. In fact, he’s wearing me out, and I think he’ll outlast me.
quotes.context: Virgil introduces his relationship with his father during the Papa Jim interview segment.

appearances.description: Appears in construction segments as “Jimmy” or “little Jimmy,” managing grading projects and later deeply involved in the golf course. Speaks about the three‑year earthmoving project and about wanting to capture the work on film.

quotes.text: It’s been a real experience for me to go through something like this, working with my dad, with the men in the company, with the laborers to the superintendents. It’s just been a real experience for me, and one I wish everyone would be able to go through someday.
quotes.context: Standing beside his father on the newly created commercial plateau, reflecting on the project and teamwork.

appearances.role: Visiting friend from San Diego, on‑camera guest
appearances.description: Identified by name (“I’m standing here with a good friend of mine, Jim Fazio from San Diego, he’s originally from Clarksburg”). Middle‑aged man in casual clothes. He praises the course’s uniqueness and predicts national exposure and strong business, calling it “the most beautiful golf course… in the United States.”

quotes.text: This is going to be the most beautiful golf course, I’m sure, in the United States, because you have certain features here… the features you have here are so unique, you will get national exposure… you’ve got a winner here, and you’ll be on top of the heap.
quotes.context: On‑camera praise from visiting friend Jim Fazio, predicting national recognition for Pete Dye Golf Club.

appearances.description: Appears with James D. near the coal‑mine hole, offering comments about the quality of a particular hole and his background in golf associations.

quotes.text: “I can tell you this: I’ve seen a lot of golf facilities throughout the country, and this undoubtedly is probably one of the finest golf holes for a real, real good golfer… Most fantastic sight, I’m very impressed.”
quotes.context: Commenting on a coal‑mine‑to‑river par‑4 hole, emphasizing its challenge and visual impact.

appearances.description: Younger man behind the bar in a white shirt. Identifies himself as “Mike Renzelli,” jokes about being on commission and about tips and football bets. Related by marriage to “Louie Rhoda.”
Older man introduced as “Mr. Whip Gabriel,” seated with his wife Julie. States he worked for the LaRosas for 21 years after 21 years in the Navy.
Sits beside Whip Gabriel; identified by him as his wife of 46 years. She does not have extended dialogue in the transcript.
One of three women introduced on camera; she gives her name and confirms they did the cooking/food prep.
Man identified on camera as “Bob Smallwood,” says he is doing general maintenance and dishwashing at the event.

Numerous women and men who give first names (e.g., Regina, Pat, Rita Forsythe, Linda Brady, Bill Belcher, Jimmy Dwine, Lois LaRosa, Mr. Bacastro, Johnny B. and Mary N. Gotti, Gary, Jack Anderson, etc.). They appear in quick interviews or greetings, representing the broader LaRosa corporate and social circle.
James D.’s son, referenced as Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Jr. He appears at the party and in the pool room, is challenged to play Willie Mosconi, and is teased about ‘sleeping in the tent’ if he loses.

Man in the kitchen/buffet area who explains the Italian dishes for the luncheon (tomato salad with Louie’s basil, sausage and peppers, shrimp a la Grelle Romeo, stuffed peppers, artichokes, baked ziti).
Several chefs in tall toques and white coats appear in the kitchen, smiling and speaking briefly to camera about preparing Italian specialties for Mr. LaRosa’s friends and the Italian Festival.
Identified on camera as ‘the Vice Mayor, Louie Aquino.’ He praises the food (anchovies, peppers, prosciutto, cheese) and appears at the luncheon as a friend of James D.

name: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

appearances.description: Named by the Sheriff and Louie: Vito and Ron Verga (Miami), Whitey Bridges (originally North Carolina, now Miami/Hialeah), Benny Lorenzo (Lorenzo’s Restaurant, North Miami), Frank Luccio (Miami), James Gwynn (California), Buzz Bozzini (lifelong buddy), and others. They appear at tables and in the pool room, often being interviewed about where they’re from and how many times they’ve visited West Virginia.
Introduces himself as Gene Glenn, Emory’s nephew, born in Clarksburg, now from Torrance, California. Talks about moving west and loving West Virginia, maybe retiring there.
Introduces himself as Julian, first cousin to Jim LaRosa (their mothers were sisters). Appears at the luncheon.
Introduce themselves as Steve Konya and his son, from Fairmont. Recall meeting Jimmy Joe at a restaurant and coming ‘to taste this good food.’

Referred to as ‘my good friend Steve Konya’ in one place and ‘Steve’ in the pool context; James D. says Steve wanted to be the next Willie Mosconi but became a coal miner. He is backed to play Willie in the pool exhibition.
Mentioned by Gene Glenn as his uncle (Emory Fazenda/Patia). Also addressed casually (“Hey Emory, you like Florida?”) during the home gathering.

name: Various women guests (Mrs. Aquinas, Mrs. Marscotti, others)

appearances.description: Women seated at tables and walking on the lawn. Louie repeatedly asks them their names and where they’re from (Philadelphia vs. Florida). They are part of the extended social circle.
